arguments.description: is the value of the parameter.

arguments.name: PATH=
arguments.description: Specify the location of an aggregate storage location or a SAS catalog for all markup files

arguments.name: 'aggregate-file-storage-location'
arguments.description: specifies an aggregate storage location such as directory, folder, or partitioned data set.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: is a file reference that has been assigned to an aggregate storage location. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref.

arguments.name: libref.catalog
arguments.description: specifies a SAS catalog to write to.

arguments.name: URL=
arguments.description: specifies a URL for the file-specification.

arguments.name: Uniform-Resource-Locator
arguments.description: is the URL that you specify. ODS uses this URL instead of the filename in all the links and references that it creates to the file.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: specifies that no information from the PATH= option appears in the links or references.

arguments.name: RECORD_SEPARATOR=
arguments.description: Specify an alternative character or string to separate lines in the output files

arguments.name: alternative-separator
arguments.description: represents one or more characters in hexadecimal or ASCII format. For example, the following option specifies a record separator for a carriage return character and a linefeed character for use with an ASCII file system:

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: produces the markup language that is appropriate for the environment where you run the SAS job.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: Specify a style template to use in writing output files

arguments.name: style-template
arguments.description: describes how to display the presentation aspects (color, font face, font size, and so on) of your SAS output. A style template determines the overall appearance of the documents that use it. Each style template consists of style elements.

arguments.name: STYLESHEET=
arguments.description: Open the HTML destination and place style information for output into an external file, or read style sheet information from an existing file

arguments.name: external-file
arguments.description: is the name of an external output file.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref.

arguments.name: entry.markup
arguments.description: specifies an entry in a SAS catalog to write to.

arguments.name: (DYNAMIC)
arguments.description: Send output directly to a web server instead of writing it to a file

arguments.name: (NO_BOTTOM_MATTER)
arguments.description: Specify that no ending markup language source code be added to the output file.

arguments.name: (NO_TOP_MATTER)
arguments.description: Specify that no beginning markup language source code be added to the top of the output file. For HTML 4.0, the NO_TOP_MATTER option removes the style sheet.

arguments.name: (TITLE='')
arguments.description: Insert into the metadata of a file, the text string that you specify as the text to appear in the browser window title bar.

arguments.name: title-text
arguments.description: is the text in the metadata of a file that indicates the title.

arguments.name: (URL= '' )
arguments.description: Specify a URL for the file-specification. ODS uses this URL (instead of the filename) in all the links and references that it creates and that point to the file.

arguments.name: TEXT=
arguments.description: Insert text into your document

arguments.name: TRANTAB=
arguments.description: Specify a translation table to use when transcoding a file for output

arguments.name: CLOSE
arguments.description: Close the destination and the file that is associated with it.

arguments.name: EXCLUDE
arguments.description: Exclude output objects from the destination

arguments.name: SELECT
arguments.description: Select output objects for the destination.

arguments.name: SHOW
arguments.description: Write to the SAS Log the current selection or exclusion list for the destination

name: ODS VERIFY
description: Prints or suppresses a message indicating that a style template or a table template being used is not supplied by SAS.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: prints the warning and sends output objects to open destinations.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: suppresses the warning.

arguments.name: ERROR
arguments.description: prints an error message instead of a warning message and does not send output objects to open destinations.

arguments.name: WARN
arguments.description: prints a warning message and does not send output objects to open destinations.

name: ODS WORD
description: Opens, manages, or closes the ODS destination for Word, which generates Microsoft Word output compatible with Microsoft Office 2010 and later versions.
help:
ODS WORD  <(<ID => identifier)> <action> ;
ODS WORD  <(<ID => identifier)> <options> ;

arguments.name: ANCHOR=
arguments.description: Specify a unique base name for the anchor tag that identifies each output object in the document

arguments.name: anchor-name
arguments.description: is the base name for the anchor tag that identifies each output object in the current chapter. ODS creates unique anchor names by incrementing the name that you specify. For example, if you specify ANCHOR='TABULATE', then ODS names the first anchor tabulate. The second anchor is named tabulate1; the third is named tabulate2, and so on.

arguments.name: AUTHOR=
arguments.description: Specify the author of the Word document

arguments.name: BASE=
arguments.description: Specify the text to use as the first part of all links and references that ODS creates in the document

arguments.name: 'base-text'
arguments.description: is the text that ODS uses as the first part of all links and references that ODS creates in the document.

arguments.name: BOX_SIZING=
arguments.description: Specify how to measure the width of cells

arguments.name: CATEGORY=
arguments.description: Specify the category of the Word document

arguments.name: COLUMNS=
arguments.description: Specify the number of columns to create on each page of output

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: is the number of one-inch columns that you want on the page.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of columns for the paper size and margin setting. This value is dependent upon the paper size and page orientation.

arguments.name: COMMENTS=
arguments.description: Add comments to the properties of the Word document

arguments.name: FILE=
arguments.description: Specify the file that contains the Word document created by the destination

arguments.name: external-file
arguments.description: is the name of an external file to receive output.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref.

arguments.name: GFOOTNOTE
arguments.description: Control the location where footnotes are printed in the graphics output

arguments.name: GFOOTNOTE
arguments.description: prints footnotes that are created by SAS/GRAPH, or the SG Procedures. The footnotes appear inside the graph borders.

arguments.name: NOGFOOTNOTE
arguments.description: prints footnotes that are created by ODS, which appear outside the graph borders.

arguments.name: NOGFOOTNOTE
arguments.description: Control the location where footnotes are printed in the graphics output

arguments.name: GFOOTNOTE
arguments.description: prints footnotes that are created by SAS/GRAPH, or the SG Procedures. The footnotes appear inside the graph borders.

arguments.name: NOGFOOTNOTE
arguments.description: prints footnotes that are created by ODS, which appear outside the graph borders.

arguments.name: GTITLE
arguments.description: Control the location where titles are printed in the graphics output

arguments.name: GTITLE
arguments.description: prints the title that is created by SAS/GRAPH or the SG Procedures. The title appears inside the graph borders.

arguments.name: NOGTITLE
arguments.description: prints the title that is created by ODS, which appears outside of the graph borders.

arguments.name: NOGTITLE
arguments.description: Control the location where titles are printed in the graphics output

arguments.name: GTITLE
arguments.description: prints the title that is created by SAS/GRAPH or the SG Procedures. The title appears inside the graph borders.

arguments.name: NOGTITLE
arguments.description: prints the title that is created by ODS, which appears outside of the graph borders.

arguments.name: IMAGE_DPI=
arguments.description: Specify the image resolution for the graphical output

arguments.name: KEYWORDS=
arguments.description: Add keywords to the Word document properties

arguments.name: (ID=)
arguments.description: Run multiple instances of the same destination at the same time. Each instance can have different options.

arguments.name: identifier
arguments.description: specifies another instance of the destination that is already open. identifier is numeric or a series of characters that begin with a letter or an underscore. Subsequent characters can include letters, underscores, and numeric characters.

arguments.name: OPTIONS
arguments.description: Specify destination-specific suboptions

arguments.name: BODY_TITLE=
arguments.description: specifies that SAS titles and footnotes are placed into the body of the document instead of the header and footer sections of the document.

arguments.name: CANT_SPLIT=
arguments.description: specifies whether all contents of a table row shall be rendered on the same page. If necessary, the start of the current row is moved to the start of a new page.

arguments.name: CONTENTS=
arguments.description: Generate a table of contents

arguments.name: FOOTER_Y=
arguments.description: Specify the distance from the bottom edge of the page to the bottom edge of the footer

arguments.name: HEADER_Y=
arguments.description: Specify the distance from the top edge of the page to the top edge of the header

arguments.name: KEEP_LINES=
arguments.description: Specify that all lines of the current paragraph should be maintained on a single page whenever possible

arguments.name: KEEP_NEXT=
arguments.description: Specify that the contents of the current paragraph are at least partly rendered on the same page as the following paragraph whenever possible

arguments.name: TOC_DATA=
arguments.description: Specify whether to capture the contents data in the document

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: contents data is not captured

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: contents data is captured

arguments.name: TOC_LEVEL=
arguments.description: Control the depth of the table of contents in the document

arguments.name: TOC_TYPE=
arguments.description: Specify whether the ODS destination for Word generates the legacy table of contents automatically, or the user generates a custom table of contents manually using nested headings

arguments.name: SASDATE
arguments.description: Insert the standard SAS date in the document in place of the default Word date and time field

arguments.name: STARTPAGE=
arguments.description: Control the insertion of new pages

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: inserts a new page when ODS or the procedure requests one.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: instructs ODS not to insert a new page, even if the procedure code requests a new page. A new page is inserted only when a page is filled or when you specify STARTPAGE= NOW.

arguments.name: NOW
arguments.description: forces the immediate insertion of a new page. Once STARTPAGE=NOW executes, the STARTPAGE= option reverts to the previously set STARTPAGE= argument. For example, if you set STARTPAGE=NO to STARTPAGE=NOW, STARTPAGE= reverts to STARTPAGE=NO.

arguments.name: BYGROUP
arguments.description: inserts a new page break after each BY group.

arguments.name: STATUS=
arguments.description: Specify the status of the document

arguments.name: SUBJECT=
arguments.description: Insert the text string that you specify as the subject in the metadata of a file

arguments.name: subject-text
arguments.description: specifies the text in the metadata of a file that indicates the subject.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: Specify the style template to apply to your output

arguments.name: style-definition
arguments.description: describes how to display the presentation aspects (color, font face, and font size) of your SAS output. A style template determines the overall appearance of the document. Each style template consists of style elements.

arguments.name: TITLE=
arguments.description: Specify the title for the document

arguments.name: WORK=
arguments.description: Specify an alternate directory for the temporary files

arguments.name: 'fileref'
arguments.description: is a file reference that has been assigned to a directory. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref.

arguments.name: 'directory-name'
arguments.description: is the name of the directory.

arguments.name: CLOSE
arguments.description: Close the destination and the file that is associated with it.

arguments.name: EXCLUDE
arguments.description: Exclude output objects from the destination

arguments.name: SELECT
arguments.description: Select output objects for the destination.

arguments.name: SHOW
arguments.description: Write to the SAS Log the current selection or exclusion list for the destination

name: ODS _ALL_ CLOSE
description: Closes all open ODS output destinations.

name: OPTIONS
description: Specifies or changes the value of one or more SAS system options.

arguments.name: options
arguments.description: specifies one or more SAS system options to be changed.

arguments.name: ACCESSIBLECHECK
arguments.description: specifies to write messages to the SAS log if common violations of accessibility standards are found.

arguments.name: ACCESSIBLEGRAPH
arguments.description: specifies to enable the ACCESSIBLE_GRAPH option in the ODS HTML5 statement by default.

arguments.name: ACCESSIBLEPDF
arguments.description: specifies to enable the ACCESSIBLE option in the ODS PDF statement.

arguments.name: ACCESSIBLETABLE
arguments.description: specifies to create accessible tables by default.

arguments.name: ANIMATION=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to start or stop creating animation frames.

arguments.name: START
arguments.description: specifies to begin creating animation frames.

arguments.name: STOP
arguments.description: specifies to stop creating animation frames.

arguments.name: ANIMDURATION=
arguments.description: Specifies the amount of time that each frame in the animation is held in view.

arguments.name: duration
arguments.description: specifies the number of seconds to hold an animation frame in view. The number can be any numeric representation (for example, .01, 5, 6.5).

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: specifies to use the device driver’s default value for the amount of time that each frame is held in view.

arguments.name: ANIMLOOP=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the animation loop is played continuously or is played once, or specifies a specific number of times that the animation loop is repeated.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that animation loops continuously repeat.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that animation loops complete one loop.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the number of times that an animation loop is continuously repeated. The number must be an integer.

arguments.name: ANIMOVERLAY
arguments.description: specifies that each frame in an animation overlays the previous frame. All frames remain in view for the duration of the animation.

arguments.name: APPEND=
arguments.description: Appends a value to the existing value of the specified system option.

arguments.name: system-option
arguments.description: In SAS Viya, system-option can be AUTOEXEC, CMPLIB, FMTSEARCH, MSG, SASAUTOS, SASHELP, SASSCRIPT, or SET.

arguments.name: argument
arguments.description: specifies a new value that you want to append to the current value of system-option.

arguments.name: AUTHINFO=
arguments.description: Specifies a file where user ID and passwords are kept for authentication.

arguments.name: AUTOCORRECT
arguments.description: specifies that SAS attempts to automatically correct misspelled procedure names, misspelled procedure keywords, or misspelled global statement names.

arguments.name: AZURETENANTID=
arguments.description: Specifies the tenant ID for connecting to a Microsoft Azure storage system

arguments.name: tenant-id
arguments.description: specifies the tenant ID, which is a GUID, for connecting to Microsoft Azure Data Lake Storage Gen2.

arguments.name: BOMFILE
arguments.description: Specifies to write a byte-order mark (BOM) prefix when a Unicode-encoded file is written to an external file.

arguments.name: BOTTOMMARGIN=
arguments.description: Specifies the size of the margin at the bottom of a printed page.

arguments.name: margin-size
arguments.description: specifies the size of the margin.

arguments.name: margin-unit
arguments.description: specifies the units for margin-size. The margin-unit can be in for inches or cm for centimeters. <margin-unit> is saved as part of the value of the BOTTOMMARGIN system option.

arguments.name: BUFNO
arguments.description: Specifies the number of buffers to be allocated for processing SAS data sets.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the number of buffers to be allocated in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the number of buffers to be allocated in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the number of buffers to be allocated in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the number of buffers to be allocated in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: specifies the number of buffers to be allocated in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the number of buffers as a hexadecimal value. You must specify the value beginning with a number (0–9), followed by an X. For example, the value 2dx specifies 45 buffers.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: sets the minimum number of buffers to 0, which causes SAS to use the minimum optimal value for the operating environment. This is the default.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: sets the number of buffers to the maximum possible number in your operating environment, up to the largest four-byte, signed integer, which is 231-1, or approximately 2 billion.

arguments.description: specifies the page size in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: T

arguments.name: BYERR
arguments.description: specifies that SAS issue an error message and stop processing if the SORT procedure attempts to sort a _NULL_ data set.

arguments.name: BYLINE
arguments.description: specifies that BY lines are printed above each BY group.

arguments.name: BYSORTED
arguments.description: specifies that observations in a data set or data sets are sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

arguments.name: CAPS
arguments.description:
specifies that SAS translate lowercase characters to uppercase in these types of input:
• data following CARDS, CARDS4, DATALINES, DATALINES4, and PARMCARDS statements
• text enclosed in single or double quotation marks
• values in VALUE and INVALUE statements in the FORMAT procedure
• titles, footnotes, variable labels, and data set labels
• constant text in macro definitions
• values of macro variables
• parameter values passed to macros.

arguments.name: CARDIMAGE
arguments.description: specifies that SAS source and data lines be processed as if they were punched card images—all exactly 80 bytes long and padded with blanks. That is, column 1 of a line is treated as if it immediately followed column 80 of the previous line. Therefore, tokens can be split across lines. (A token is a character or series of characters that SAS treats as a discrete word.)

arguments.name: CASDATALIMIT=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of bytes of data from a single CAS table that can be transferred from the CAS server to SAS.

arguments.name: CASHOST=
arguments.description: Specifies the CAS server that is associated with a CAS session.

arguments.name: CASLIB=
arguments.description: Specifies the caslib name for the session that is identified by the SESSREF= option.

arguments.name: CASNCHARMULTIPLIER=
arguments.description: Specifies a multiplication factor that is used to increase the number of bytes for a fixed character variable when using the CAS LIBNAME engine and data is transcoded to the UTF-8 encoding in order to run in the CAS server.

arguments.name: CASNWORKERS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of worker nodes to use for a CAS session.

arguments.name: CASPORT=
arguments.description: Specifies the port to use when connecting to CAS.

arguments.name: CASSESSOPTS=
arguments.description: Specifies one or more session options for the active CAS session.

arguments.name: CASTIMEOUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the CAS session time-out in seconds for new sessions. The session time-out starts when the number of connections to the session becomes zero and all session activity is complete.

arguments.name: CASUSER=
arguments.description: Specifies the user ID to use when connecting to CAS.

arguments.name: CBUFNO=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of extra page buffers to allocate for each open SAS catalog.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the number of extra page buffers in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes; 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the number of extra page buffers in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes; 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the number of extra page buffers in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes; 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the number of extra page buffers in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes; 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: specifies the number of extra page buffers in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes; 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: sets the number of extra page buffers to 0.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: sets the number of extra page buffers to 20.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the number of extra page buffers as a hexadecimal number. The value must begin with a number (0–9) and must be followed by an X. For example, the value 0ax sets the number of extra page buffers to 10.

arguments.name: CENTER
arguments.description: centers SAS procedure output.

arguments.name: CGOPTIMIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the level of optimization to perform during code compilation.
specifies not to perform optimization.

specifies to perform stage 1 optimization. Stage 1 optimization removes redundant instructions, missing value checks, and repetitive computations for array subscriptions; detects patterns of instructions and replaces them with more efficient sequences.
specifies to perform stage 2 optimization. Stage 2 performs optimizations that pertain to the SAS register.
specifies to perform full optimization, which is a combination of stages 1 and 2.

arguments.name: CHARCODE
arguments.description: allows certain character combinations to be substituted for special characters that might not be on your keyboard.

arguments.name: CLEANUP
arguments.description: specifies that during the entire session, SAS attempts to perform automatic, continuous cleanup of resources that are not essential for execution. Nonessential resources include resources that are not visible to the user (for example, cache memory) and resources that are visible to the user (for example, the KEYS windows).

arguments.name: CMPLIB=
arguments.description: Specifies one or more SAS data sets that contain compiler subroutines to include during program compilation.

arguments.name: libref.data-set
arguments.description: specifies the libref and the data set of the compiler subroutines that are to be included during program compilation. The libref and data-set must be valid SAS names.

arguments.name: libref.data-set-m
arguments.description: specifies a range of compiler subroutines that are to be included during program compilation. The name of the libref and the data set must be valid SAS names that contain a numeric suffix.

arguments.name: CMPMODEL
arguments.description: Specifies the output model type for the MODEL procedure.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: specifies that the MODEL procedure create two output types for a model, one as a SAS catalog entry and the other as an XML file.

arguments.name: CATALOG
arguments.description: specifies that the output model type is an entry in a SAS catalog.

arguments.name: XML
arguments.description: specifies that the output model type is an XML file.

arguments.name: CMPOPT=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of code generation optimizations to use in the SAS language compiler.

arguments.name: CONSTANTFOLDING
arguments.description: specifies to evaluate numeric and character literal expressions at compile time for supported operations. When you specify NOCONSTANTFOLDING, numeric and character literal expressions are evaluated at runtime.

arguments.name: NOCONSTANTFOLDING
arguments.description: specifies to evaluate numeric and character literal expressions at compile time for supported operations. When you specify NOCONSTANTFOLDING, numeric and character literal expressions are evaluated at runtime.

arguments.name: EXTRAMATH
arguments.description: specifies to keep or remove mathematical operations that do not affect the outcome of a statement. When you specify EXTRAMATH, the compiler retains the extra mathematical operations. When you specify NOEXTRAMATH, the extra mathematical operations are removed.

arguments.name: NOEXTRAMATH
arguments.description: specifies to keep or remove mathematical operations that do not affect the outcome of a statement. When you specify EXTRAMATH, the compiler retains the extra mathematical operations. When you specify NOEXTRAMATH, the extra mathematical operations are removed.

arguments.name: FUNCDIFFERENCING
arguments.description: specifies whether analytic derivatives are computed for user-defined functions. When you specify NOFUNCDIFFERENCING, analytic derivatives are computed for user-defined functions. When you specify FUNCDIFFERENCING, numeric differencing is used to calculate derivatives for user-defined functions. The default is NOFUNCDIFFERENCING.

arguments.name: NOFUNCDIFFERENCING
arguments.description: specifies whether analytic derivatives are computed for user-defined functions. When you specify NOFUNCDIFFERENCING, analytic derivatives are computed for user-defined functions. When you specify FUNCDIFFERENCING, numeric differencing is used to calculate derivatives for user-defined functions. The default is NOFUNCDIFFERENCING.

arguments.name: GUARDCHECK
arguments.description: specifies whether to check for array boundary problems. When you specify GUARDCHECK, the compiler checks for array boundary problems. When you specify NOGUARDCHECK, the compiler does not check for array boundary problems.

arguments.name: NOGUARDCHECK
arguments.description: specifies whether to check for array boundary problems. When you specify GUARDCHECK, the compiler checks for array boundary problems. When you specify NOGUARDCHECK, the compiler does not check for array boundary problems.

arguments.name: MISSCHECK
arguments.description: specifies whether to check for missing values in the data. If the data contains a significant amount of missing data, then you can optimize the compilation by specifying MISSCHECK. If the data rarely contains missing values, then you can optimize the compilation by specifying NOMISSCHECK.

arguments.name: NOMISSCHECK
arguments.description: specifies whether to check for missing values in the data. If the data contains a significant amount of missing data, then you can optimize the compilation by specifying MISSCHECK. If the data rarely contains missing values, then you can optimize the compilation by specifying NOMISSCHECK.

arguments.name: PRECISE
arguments.description: specifies to handle exceptions at an operation boundary or at a statement boundary. When you specify PRECISE, exceptions are handled at the operation boundary. When you specify NOPRECISE, exceptions are handled at the statement boundary.

arguments.name: NOPRECISE
arguments.description: specifies to handle exceptions at an operation boundary or at a statement boundary. When you specify PRECISE, exceptions are handled at the operation boundary. When you specify NOPRECISE, exceptions are handled at the statement boundary.

arguments.name: PROFILE
arguments.description: specifies to append to the end of the profiling data set the total execution time for each function in a CMP statement.

arguments.name: NOPROFILE
arguments.description: specifies to append to the end of the profiling data set the total execution time for each function in a CMP statement.

arguments.name: SHORTCIRCUIT
arguments.description: specifies whether to optimize the evaluation of expressions that use multiple logical operators.

arguments.name: NOSHORTCIRCUIT
arguments.description: specifies whether to optimize the evaluation of expressions that use multiple logical operators.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: specifies that the compiler is to optimize the machine language code by using the (CONSTANTFOLDING NOEXTRAMATH NOMISSCHECK NOPRECISE NOFUNCDIFFERENCING SHORTCIRCUIT) optimization values.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: specifies that the compiler is not set to optimize the machine language code by using the (NOCONSTANTFOLDING EXTRAMATH MISSCHECK PRECISE FUNCDIFFERENCING NOSHORTCIRCUIT) optimization values.

arguments.name: COLOPHON=
arguments.description: Specifies a text string that is embedded in a graphic file or a PDF that is created by Universal Printers. The text string is not displayed in the rendered graphic or PDF.

arguments.name: text-string
arguments.description: specifies the text that is embedded in a graphic file.

arguments.name: COLORPRINTING
arguments.description: specifies to attempt to print in color.

arguments.name: COMPRESS=
arguments.description: Specifies to compress SPD Engine data sets on disk as they are being created.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: performs no data set compression.

arguments.name: CHAR
arguments.description: specifies that data in an SPD Engine data set be compressed in blocks by using RLE (run-length encoding). RLE compresses data by reducing repeated runs of the same character (including a blank space) to two-byte or three-byte representations.

arguments.name: BINARY
arguments.description: specifies that data in an SPD Engine data set be compressed in blocks by using RDC (Ross Data Compression). RDC combines RLE and sliding window compression to compress the file by representing repeated byte patterns more efficiently.

arguments.name: CPUCOUNT=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of processors that the thread-enabled applications should assume are available for concurrent processing.
is the number of CPUs that SAS assumes are available for use by thread-enabled applications.

arguments.name: ACTUAL
arguments.description: returns the number of physical processors that are associated with the operating system where SAS is executing. If the operating system is executing in a partition, the value of the CPUCOUNT= option is the number of physical processors that are associated with the operating system in that partition.

arguments.name: DATASTMTCHK=
arguments.description: Specifies which SAS statement keywords are prohibited from being specified as a one-level DATA step name to protect against overwriting an input data set.

arguments.name: COREKEYWORDS
arguments.description:
prohibits certain words as one-level SAS data set names in the DATA statement. They can appear as two-level names. The following keywords cannot appear as one-level SAS data set names:
• MERGE
• RETAIN
• SET
• UPDATE.

arguments.name: ALLKEYWORDS
arguments.description: prohibits any keyword that can begin a statement in the DATA step (for example, ABORT, ARRAY, INFILE) as a one-level data set name in the DATA statement.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: provides no protection against overwriting SAS data sets.

arguments.name: DATE
arguments.description: specifies that the date and the time at which the SAS program started are printed at the top of each page of the SAS log and any output that is created by SAS.

arguments.name: DATESTYLE=
arguments.description: Specifies the sequence of month, day, and year when ANYDTDTE, ANYDTDTM, or ANYDTTME informat data is ambiguous.

arguments.name: MDY
arguments.description: specifies that SAS set the order as month, day, year.

arguments.name: YMD
arguments.description: specifies that SAS set the order as year, month, day.

arguments.name: DMY
arguments.description: specifies that SAS set the order as day, month, year.

arguments.name: LOCALE
arguments.description: specifies that SAS set the order based on the value that corresponds to the LOCALE= system option value and is one of the following: MDY | YMD | DMY.

arguments.name: DBFMTIGNORE
arguments.description: specifies that numeric formats are ignored and FLOAT data type is created.

arguments.name: DBIDIRECTEXEC
arguments.description: indicates that the SQL pass-through facility optimizes handling of SQL statements by passing them directly to the database for execution, which optimizes performance. Using this option, you can process CREATE TABLE AS SELECT, INSERT INTO TABLE, INSERT INTO VALUES, UPDATE, and DELETE statements for the SQL procedure.

arguments.name: DBSLICEPARM=
arguments.description: Controls the scope of DBMS threaded Reads and the number of threads.
arguments.help: DBSLICEPARM= NONE | THREADED_APPS | ALL\nDBSLICEPARM= (NONE | THREADED_APPS | *ALL*<*max-threads*> )\nDBSLICEPARM= (NONE | THREADED_APPS | *ALL*<, *max-threads*>)

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: disables DBMS threaded Read. SAS reads tables on a single DBMS connection.

arguments.name: THREADED_APPS
arguments.description: makes fully threaded SAS procedures (threaded applications) eligible for threaded Reads.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: makes all read-only librefs eligible for threaded Reads. This includes SAS threaded applications, as well as the SAS DATA step and numerous SAS procedures.

arguments.name: DEBUGOPT=
arguments.description: Specifies the host and port where debugging SAS languages occurs

arguments.name: DEBUGHOST=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the host where debugging occurs. The maximum number of characters is 1,024.

arguments.name: DEBUGPORT=
arguments.description: specifies the port number of the host where debugging occurs.

arguments.name: DECIMALCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the binary to decimal conversion and formatting methodology.

arguments.name: COMPATIBLE
arguments.description: Use this option when SAS output might be processed by existing applications that are sensitive to the details of formatting.

arguments.name: STDIEEE
arguments.description: specifies to convert and format decimal values by using the IEEE Standard for Floating-Point Arithmetic 754-2008. Using the STDIEEE argument improves the accuracy and readability of floating-point numbers. In some cases, more significant digits can be displayed in the same field width.

arguments.name: DETAILS
arguments.description: includes additional information when some SAS procedures and windows display a listing of files in a SAS library.

arguments.name: DEVICE=
arguments.description: Specifies the device driver to which SAS/GRAPH sends procedure output.

arguments.name: device-driver-specification
arguments.description: specifies the name of a device driver.

arguments.name: DFLANG=
arguments.description: Specifies the language for international date informats and formats.

arguments.name: 'language'
arguments.description: specifies the language that is used for international date informats and formats.

arguments.name: LOCALE
arguments.description: the locale that is specified with the LOCALE system option becomes the active locale.

arguments.name: DKRICOND=
arguments.description: Specifies the level of error detection to report when a variable is missing from an input data set during the processing of a DROP=, KEEP=, or RENAME= data set option.

arguments.name: ERROR
arguments.description: sets the error flag and writes an error message to the SAS log when a variable is missing from an input data set during the processing of a DROP=, KEEP=, or RENAME= data set option.

arguments.name: WARNING
arguments.description: writes a warning message to the SAS log when a variable is missing from an input data set during the processing of a DROP=, KEEP=, or RENAME= data set option.

arguments.name: NOWARNING
arguments.description: does not write a warning message to the SAS log when a variable is missing from an input data set during the processing of a DROP=, KEEP=, or RENAME= data set option.

arguments.name: DKROCOND=
arguments.description: Specifies the level of error detection to report when a variable is missing for an output data set during the processing of a DROP=, KEEP=, or RENAME= data set option.

arguments.name: ERROR
arguments.description: sets the error flag and writes an error message to the SAS log when a variable is missing for an output data set during the processing of a DROP=, KEEP=, or RENAME= data set option.

arguments.name: WARNING
arguments.description: writes a warning message to the SAS log when a variable is missing for an output data set during the processing of a DROP=, KEEP=, or RENAME= data set option.

arguments.name: NOWARNING
arguments.description: does not write a warning message to the SAS log when a variable is missing for an output data set during the processing of a DROP=, KEEP=, or RENAME= data set option.

arguments.name: DLCREATEDIR
arguments.description: specifies to create a directory for a SAS library that is named in a LIBNAME statement if the directory does not exist.

arguments.name: DLDMGACTION=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of action to take when a SAS data set or a SAS catalog is detected as damaged.
arguments.help: DLDMGACTION= FAIL | ABORT | REPAIR | NOINDEX | PROMPT

arguments.name: FAIL
arguments.description: stops the step and issues an error message to the log immediately.

arguments.name: ABORT
arguments.description: terminates the step and issues an error message to the log, and ends the SAS session.

arguments.name: REPAIR
arguments.description: For data files, automatically repairs and rebuilds indexes and integrity constraints, unless the data file is truncated. You use the REPAIR statement to restore the truncated data file. It issues a warning message to the log. For catalogs, REPAIR automatically deletes catalog entries for which an error occurs during the repair process.

arguments.name: NOINDEX
arguments.description: For data files, automatically repairs the data file without the indexes and integrity constraints, deletes the index file, updates the data file to reflect the disabled indexes and integrity constraints, and limits the data file to be opened only in INPUT mode. A warning is written to the SAS log instructing you to execute the PROC DATASETS REBUILD statement to correct or delete the disabled indexes and integrity constraints.

arguments.name: PROMPT
arguments.description: For data sets, displays a dialog box where you can specify either FAIL, ABORT, REPAIR, or NOINDEX. For a damaged catalog or library, PROMPT displays a dialog box where you can specify either FAIL, ABORT, or REPAIR.

arguments.name: DQLOCALE=
arguments.description: Specifies a locale, or an ordered list of locales

arguments.name: locale-1
arguments.description: specifies the QKB ISO codes for the default locale.

arguments.name: locale-2,
arguments.description: specifies an optional ordered list of locales. The ordered list is used only for locale guessing with the DQLOCALEGUESS function. If a list is specified, the default locale is the first locale in the list. All of the locales in the list must exist in the Quality Knowledge Base.

arguments.name: DQOPTIONS=
arguments.description: Specifies SAS session parameters for data quality programs.

arguments.name: DQSRVPROTOCOL=
arguments.description: specifies the SAS Data Quality Server protocol. In operating environments, other than z/OS, the default SOAP protocol is recommended.

arguments.name: SOAP
arguments.description: specifies to use the Simple Object Access Protocol (SOAP).

arguments.name: WIRELINE
arguments.description: specifies the Wireline protocol in the z/OS operating environment. The Wireline protocol improves data transfer performance in z/OS. In the SAS Data Quality Server software, z/OS support encompasses the DMSRVDATASVC procedure and all functions.

arguments.name: TRANSCODE=
arguments.description:
specifies whether transcoding errors end SAS processing.
• Errors can also occur when transcoding the 's character set into the character set that is used in the SAS session. 
• Transcoding errors can occur if characters in the source data cannot be converted into the character set that is used by the selected .

arguments.name: IGNORE
arguments.description: prevents writing of transcoding warning messages to the SAS log. SAS processing continues and ignores any transcoding errors.

arguments.name: WARN
arguments.description: writes transcoding error messages to the SAS log, and SAS stops processing.

arguments.name: DQSETUPLOC=
arguments.description: Specifies the location of the root directory of the Quality Knowledge Base.

arguments.name: qkb-name
arguments.description: The name of the Quality Knowledge Base. The default value is QKB CI 33.

arguments.name: DS2SCOND=
arguments.description: Specifies the level of messages that PROC DS2 displays in the SAS log for the DS2 variable declaration strict mode, which requires that every variable must be declared in the DS2 program.

arguments.name: ERROR
arguments.description: writes error messages to the SAS log.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: no messages are written to the SAS log.

arguments.name: NOTE
arguments.description: writes notes to the SAS log.

arguments.name: WARNING
arguments.description: writes warning messages to the SAS log. This is the default.

arguments.name: DSNFERR
arguments.description: specifies that SAS issue an error message and stop processing if a reference is made to a SAS data set that does not exist.

arguments.name: DTRESET
arguments.description: specifies that SAS update the date and time in the titles of the SAS log and the procedure output file.

arguments.name: ECHOAUTO
arguments.description: specifies that the SAS statements in the AUTOEXEC= file are written to the SAS log as they are executed.

arguments.name: EMAILACKWAIT=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of seconds that SAS waits to receive an acknowledgment from an SMTP server.

arguments.name: number-of-seconds
arguments.description: specifies the number of seconds that SAS waits to receive an acknowledgment from an SMTP server.

arguments.name: EMAILAUTHPROTOCOL=
arguments.description: Specifies the authentication protocol for SMTP email.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: specifies that no authentication protocol is used.

arguments.name: LOGIN
arguments.description: specifies that the LOGIN authentication protocol is used.

arguments.name: PLAIN
arguments.description: specifies that the PLAIN authentication protocol is used. The PLAIN authentication protocol encodes the user ID and password in BASE64 and encodes them as one string.

arguments.name: EMAILFROM
arguments.description: specifies that the FROM email option is required when sending email by using either the FILE or FILENAME statements.

arguments.name: EMAILHOST=
arguments.description: Specifies one or more SMTP servers that support email access.

arguments.name: server
arguments.description: specifies one or more Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) server domain names for your site.

arguments.name: EMAILID
arguments.description: Identifies an email sender by specifying either a logon ID, an email profile, or an email address.

arguments.name: logonid
arguments.description: specifies the logon ID for the user running SAS.

arguments.name: profile
arguments.description: see documentation for your email system to determine the profile name.

arguments.name: email-address
arguments.description: specifies the fully qualified email address of the user running SAS.

arguments.name: EMAILPORT=
arguments.description: Specifies the port that the SMTP server is attached to.

arguments.name: port-number
arguments.description: specifies the port number that is used by the SMTP server that you specified on the EMAILHOST option.

arguments.name: EMAILPW=
arguments.description: Specifies an email logon password.

arguments.name: password
arguments.description: specifies the logon password for your logon name.

arguments.name: EMAILUTCOFFSET=
arguments.description: For email that is sent using the FILENAME statement EMAIL (SMTP) access method, specifies a UTC offset that is used in the Date header field of the email message.

arguments.name: "+hhmm"
arguments.description: specifies the number of hours and minutes that are used as the UTC offset in the Date header field of an email. Use the UTC offset to establish the local time.

arguments.name: "-hhmm"
arguments.description: specifies the number of hours and minutes that are used as the UTC offset in the Date header field of an email. Use the UTC offset to establish the local time.

arguments.name: ERRORABEND
arguments.description: specifies that SAS terminate for most errors (including syntax errors and file not found errors) that would normally cause it to issue an error message, set OBS=0, and go into syntax-check mode (if syntax checking is enabled). SAS also terminates if an error occurs in any global statement other than the LIBNAME and FILENAME statements.

arguments.name: ERRORBYABEND
arguments.description: specifies that SAS ends a program for BY-group error conditions that would normally cause it to issue an error message.

arguments.name: ERRORCHECK=
arguments.description: Specifies whether SAS enters syntax-check mode when errors are found in the LIBNAME, FILENAME, %INCLUDE, and LOCK statements.

arguments.name: NORMAL
arguments.description: specifies not to place the SAS program into syntax-check mode when an error occurs in a LIBNAME or FILENAME statement. In addition, the program or session does not terminate when a %INCLUDE statement fails due to a non-existent file.

arguments.name: STRICT
arguments.description: specifies to place the SAS program into syntax-check mode when an error occurs in a LIBNAME or FILENAME statement. If the ERRORABEND system option is set and an error occurs in either a LIBNAME or FILENAME statement, SAS terminates. In addition, SAS terminates when a %INCLUDE statement fails due to a non-existent file.

arguments.name: ERRORS=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of observations for which SAS issues complete error messages.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the number of observations for which SAS issues error messages in terms of 1 (n); 1,024 (nK); 1,048,576 (nM); 1,073,741,824 (nG); or 1,099,511,627,776 (nT). For example, a value of 8 specifies eight observations, and a value of 3M specifies 3,145,728 observations.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the number of observations for which SAS issues error messages in terms of 1 (n); 1,024 (nK); 1,048,576 (nM); 1,073,741,824 (nG); or 1,099,511,627,776 (nT). For example, a value of 8 specifies eight observations, and a value of 3M specifies 3,145,728 observations.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the number of observations for which SAS issues error messages in terms of 1 (n); 1,024 (nK); 1,048,576 (nM); 1,073,741,824 (nG); or 1,099,511,627,776 (nT). For example, a value of 8 specifies eight observations, and a value of 3M specifies 3,145,728 observations.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the number of observations for which SAS issues error messages in terms of 1 (n); 1,024 (nK); 1,048,576 (nM); 1,073,741,824 (nG); or 1,099,511,627,776 (nT). For example, a value of 8 specifies eight observations, and a value of 3M specifies 3,145,728 observations.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: specifies the number of observations for which SAS issues error messages in terms of 1 (n); 1,024 (nK); 1,048,576 (nM); 1,073,741,824 (nG); or 1,099,511,627,776 (nT). For example, a value of 8 specifies eight observations, and a value of 3M specifies 3,145,728 observations.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: sets the number of observations for which SAS issues error messages to 0.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: sets the maximum number of observations for which SAS issues error messages to the largest signed, 4-byte integer representable in your operating environment.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of observations for which SAS issues error messages as a hexadecimal number. The value must begin with a number (0–9) and must be followed by an X. For example, the value 2dx sets the maximum number of observations for which SAS issues error messages to 45 observations.

arguments.name: EVENTDS=
arguments.description: Specifies one or more data sets that define events.

arguments.name: DEFAULTS
arguments.description: specifies to use the SAS predefined holiday events.

arguments.name: NODEFAULTS
arguments.description: specifies not to use default event definitions. The only events that are used are specified by the event-data-set list.

arguments.name: event-data-set
arguments.description: specifies the name of a data set that contains event definitions. The data set can be specified as a one-level name, dataset, or a two-level name, libref.dataset.

arguments.name: EXTENDOBSCOUNTER
arguments.description: Specifies whether to extend the maximum observation count in a new output SAS data file.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies to use the default maximum observation count of 231–1 or approximately 9.2 quintillion observations in a newly created SAS data file.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: is a compatibility setting for a newly created SAS data file, to enable its use in releases prior to SAS 9.3.

arguments.name: FILELOCKS
arguments.description: Specifies whether file locking is turned on or off and what action should be taken if a file cannot be locked.

arguments.name: setting
arguments.description:
specifies the operating environment locking value for the specified path. The following values are valid:
• NONE
• FAIL
• CONTINUE
• RESET

arguments.name: path
arguments.description: specifies a path to a Linux directory. Enclose the path in single or double quotation marks.

arguments.name: FIRSTOBS
arguments.description: Specifies the row number or external file record that SAS processes first.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the number of the first row or external file record to process in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the number of the first row or external file record to process in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the number of the first row or external file record to process in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the number of the first row or external file record to process in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: specifies the number of the first row or external file record to process in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the number of the first row or the external file record to process as a hexadecimal value. You must specify the value beginning with a number (0–9), followed by an X. For example, the value 2dx specifies the 45th row.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: sets the number of the first row or external file record to process to 1. This is the default.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: sets the number of the first row to process to the maximum number of rows in the data sets or records in the external file, up to the largest eight-byte, signed integer, which is 263-1, or approximately 9.2 quintillion rows.

arguments.name: FIRSTOBS=
arguments.description: Specifies the observation number or external file record that SAS processes first.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the number of the first observation or external file record to process, where n is an integer. Using one of the letter notations results in multiplying the integer by a specific value. That is, specifying K (kilo) multiplies the integer by 1,024; M (mega) multiplies by 1,048,576 ; G (giga) multiplies by 1,073,741,824; or T (tera) multiplies by 1,099,511,627,776. For example, a value of 8 specifies the eighth observations or records, and a value of 3m specifies observation or record 3,145,728.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the number of the first observation or external file record to process, where n is an integer. Using one of the letter notations results in multiplying the integer by a specific value. That is, specifying K (kilo) multiplies the integer by 1,024; M (mega) multiplies by 1,048,576 ; G (giga) multiplies by 1,073,741,824; or T (tera) multiplies by 1,099,511,627,776. For example, a value of 8 specifies the eighth observations or records, and a value of 3m specifies observation or record 3,145,728.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the number of the first observation or external file record to process, where n is an integer. Using one of the letter notations results in multiplying the integer by a specific value. That is, specifying K (kilo) multiplies the integer by 1,024; M (mega) multiplies by 1,048,576 ; G (giga) multiplies by 1,073,741,824; or T (tera) multiplies by 1,099,511,627,776. For example, a value of 8 specifies the eighth observations or records, and a value of 3m specifies observation or record 3,145,728.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the number of the first observation or external file record to process, where n is an integer. Using one of the letter notations results in multiplying the integer by a specific value. That is, specifying K (kilo) multiplies the integer by 1,024; M (mega) multiplies by 1,048,576 ; G (giga) multiplies by 1,073,741,824; or T (tera) multiplies by 1,099,511,627,776. For example, a value of 8 specifies the eighth observations or records, and a value of 3m specifies observation or record 3,145,728.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: specifies the number of the first observation or external file record to process, where n is an integer. Using one of the letter notations results in multiplying the integer by a specific value. That is, specifying K (kilo) multiplies the integer by 1,024; M (mega) multiplies by 1,048,576 ; G (giga) multiplies by 1,073,741,824; or T (tera) multiplies by 1,099,511,627,776. For example, a value of 8 specifies the eighth observations or records, and a value of 3m specifies observation or record 3,145,728.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the number of the first observation or the external file record to process as a hexadecimal value. The value must begin with a number (0–9) and must be followed by an X. For example, the value 2dx specifies the 45th observation.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: sets the number of the first observation or external file record to process to 1. This is the default.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: sets the number of the first observation to process to the maximum number of observations in the data sets or records in the external file, up to the largest eight-byte, signed integer, which is 263-1, or approximately 9.2 quintillion observations.

arguments.name: FMTERR
arguments.description: specifies that when SAS cannot find a specified variable format, it generates an error message and does not allow default substitution to occur.

arguments.name: FMTSEARCH=
arguments.description: Specifies the order in which format catalogs are searched.

arguments.name: libref/LOCALE
arguments.description: specifies to search the FORMATS catalog in the storage location that is specified by libref. When a libref is specified without a catalog, SAS uses FORMATS as the default catalog name.

arguments.name: libref.catalog/LOCALE
arguments.description: specifies to search for a specific library and catalog.

arguments.name: FONTEMBEDDING
arguments.description: specifies to enable font embedding.

arguments.name: FORMCHAR
arguments.description: Specifies the default output formatting characters.

arguments.name: 'formatting-characters'
arguments.description: specifies any string or list of strings of characters up to 64 bytes long. If fewer than 64 bytes are specified, the string is padded with blanks on the right.

arguments.name: FULLSTIMER
arguments.description: writes to the SAS log a list of the host-dependent resources that were used for each step and for the entire SAS session. A datetime stamp is included in the output.

arguments.name: GSTYLE
arguments.description: specifies that ODS styles are used in the generation of graphs that are stored as GRSEG catalog entries. If no style is specified, the default style for the ODS destination is used. GSTYLE is always in effect. System option NOGSTYLE is no longer supported.

arguments.name: HOSTINFOLONG
arguments.description: specifies to print additional operating environment information in the SAS log when SAS starts.

arguments.name: IBUFNO=
arguments.description: Specifies an optional number of extra buffers to be allocated for navigating an index file.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the number of extra index buffers to be allocated in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies eight buffers, and a value of 3k specifies 3,072 buffers.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the number of extra index buffers to be allocated in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies eight buffers, and a value of 3k specifies 3,072 buffers.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the number of extra index buffers to be allocated in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies eight buffers, and a value of 3k specifies 3,072 buffers.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the number of extra index buffers to be allocated in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies eight buffers, and a value of 3k specifies 3,072 buffers.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: specifies the number of extra index buffers to be allocated in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies eight buffers, and a value of 3k specifies 3,072 buffers.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the number of extra index buffers as a hexadecimal value. The value must begin with a number (0–9) and must be followed by an X. For example, the value 2dx specifies 45 buffers.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: sets the number of extra index buffers to 0.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: sets the maximum number of extra index buffers to 10,000.

arguments.name: IBUFSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the buffer size for an index file.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the buffer size to process in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3k specifies 3,072 bytes. A value of 0 causes SAS to use the minimum optimal buffer size for the operating environment.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the buffer size to process in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3k specifies 3,072 bytes. A value of 0 causes SAS to use the minimum optimal buffer size for the operating environment.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the buffer size to process in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3k specifies 3,072 bytes. A value of 0 causes SAS to use the minimum optimal buffer size for the operating environment.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the buffer size to process in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3k specifies 3,072 bytes. A value of 0 causes SAS to use the minimum optimal buffer size for the operating environment.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: specifies the buffer size to process in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3k specifies 3,072 bytes. A value of 0 causes SAS to use the minimum optimal buffer size for the operating environment.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the buffer size as a hexadecimal value. The value must begin with a number (0–9) and must be followed by an X. For example, the value 2dx sets the page size to 45 bytes.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: sets the buffer size for an index file to the maximum possible number. For IBUFSIZE=, the value is 32,767 bytes.

arguments.name: IMLPACKAGEPRIVATE=
arguments.description: Specifies the directory for the private collection of SAS/IML packages.

arguments.name: directory-path
arguments.description: specifies the directory where the private collection of SAS/IML packages is stored. Packages in the private collection are available only to the current user. The directory specified by this option should be unique for each user.

arguments.name: IMLPACKAGEPUBLIC=
arguments.description: Specifies the directory for the public collection of SAS/IML packages.

arguments.name: directory-path
arguments.description: specifies the directory where the public collection of SAS/IML packages is stored. Packages in the public collection are available to all users of the system. directory-path should be accessible by all users.

arguments.name: IMLPACKAGESYSTEM=
arguments.description: Specifies the directory for packages that are installed as part of SAS/IML.

arguments.name: directory-path
arguments.description: specifies the directory where the system collection of SAS/IML packages is stored. Packages in the system collection are installed as part of SAS/IML software and are available to all users of the system.

arguments.name: INITSTMT=
arguments.description: Specifies a SAS statement to execute after any statements in the AUTOEXEC= file and before any statements from the SYSIN= file.

arguments.name: 'statement'
arguments.description: specifies any SAS statement or statements.

arguments.name: INSERT=
arguments.description: Inserts the specified value as the first value of the specified system option.

arguments.name: system-option
arguments.description: In SAS Viya, can be AUTOEXEC, CMPLIB, FMTSEARCH, MAPSGFK, MSG, SASAUTOS, SASHELP, SASSCRIPT, or SET.

arguments.name: argument
arguments.description: specifies a new value that you want as the first value of system-option.

arguments.name: INTERVALDS=
arguments.description: Specifies one or more interval name-value pairs, where the value is a SAS data set that contains user-defined intervals. The intervals can be used as arguments to the INTNX and INTCK functions.

arguments.name: interval
arguments.description: specifies the name of an interval. The value of interval is used to represent the set of intervals that is specified in libref.dataset-name.

arguments.name: libref.dataset-name
arguments.description: specifies the libref and the data set name of the file that contains the user-defined intervals.

arguments.name: INVALIDDATA=
arguments.description: Specifies the value that SAS assigns to a variable when invalid numeric data is encountered.

arguments.name: 'character'
arguments.description: specifies the value to be assigned, which can be a letter (A through Z, a through z), a period (.), or an underscore (_).

arguments.name: JPEGQUALITY=
arguments.description: Specifies the JPEG quality factor that determines the ratio of image quality to the level of compression for JPEG files produced by the SAS/GRAPH JPEG device driver.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies an integer that indicates the JPEG quality factor. The quality of the image increases with larger numbers and decreases with smaller numbers. JPEG files are compressed less for higher-quality images. Therefore, the JPEG file size is greater for higher-quality images. For example, n=100 is completely uncompressed and the image quality is highest. When n=0, the image is produced at the maximum compression level with the lowest quality.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: specifies to set the JPEG quality factor to 0, which has the lowest image quality and the greatest file compression.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: specifies to set the JPEG quality factor to 100, which has the highest image quality with no file compression.

arguments.name: LABEL
arguments.description: specifies that SAS procedures can use labels with variables. The LABEL system option must be in effect before the LABEL option of any procedure can be used.

arguments.name: LEFTMARGIN=
arguments.description: Specifies the print margin for the left side of the page.

arguments.name: margin-size
arguments.description: specifies the size of the left print margin.

arguments.name: <margin-unit>
arguments.description: specifies the units for margin-size. The margin-unit can be in for inches or cm for centimeters. <margin-unit> is saved as part of the value of the LEFTMARGIN system option whether it is specified.

arguments.name: LINESIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the line size for the SAS log and for SAS procedure output.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the number of characters in a line.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: sets the number of characters in a line to 64.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: sets the number of characters in a line to 256.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the number of characters in a line as a hexadecimal number. The value must begin with a number (0–9) and must be followed by an X. For example, the value 0FAx sets the line size of the SAS procedure output to 250.

arguments.name: LOCALE=
arguments.description: Specifies a set of attributes in a SAS session that reflect the language, local conventions, and culture for a geographical region.

arguments.name: LPTYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies which Linux command and option settings are used to route files to the printer.

arguments.name: BSD
arguments.description: causes SAS to use the lpr command to send files to the printer. The lpr command is typically supported on Linux operating systems.

arguments.name: SYSV
arguments.description: causes SAS to use the lp command to send files to the printer. The lp command is usually supported on operating systems derived from Linux System V.

arguments.name: LRECL=
arguments.description: Specifies the default logical record length to use for reading and writing external files.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the logical record length in multiples of 1 (bytes) or 1,024 (kilobytes). For example, a value of 32 specifies 32 bytes, and a value of 16k specifies 16,384 bytes.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the logical record length as a hexadecimal value. The value must begin with a number (0–9) and must be followed by an X. For example, the value 2dx sets the logical record length to 45 characters.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: specifies a logical record length of 1.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: specifies a logical record length of 32,767.

arguments.name: MAPS
arguments.description: Specifies the name of the SAS library containing the SAS/GRAPH map data sets.

arguments.name: location-of-maps
arguments.description: specifies a libref, a valid Linux pathname, or an environment variable associated with a pathname. Do not use a specific filename.

arguments.name: MAPS=
arguments.description: Specifies the location of the SAS library that contains SAS/GRAPH map data sets.

arguments.name: location-of-maps
arguments.description: specifies either a physical path, an environment variable, or a libref to locate the SAS/GRAPH map data sets.

arguments.name: MAPSGFK=
arguments.description: Specifies the location of the SAS library that contains SAS/GRAPH digital vector map data sets. The libref MAPSGFK is assigned using the option value specified by the MAPSGFK= system option.

arguments.name: location-of-maps
arguments.description: specifies either a physical path, an environment variable, or the MAPSGFK libref to locate the SAS/GRAPH digital vector map data sets. The option value can consist of up to 2048 characters. Upper or lower case characters are accepted as entered. Though not required, if you specify start and end quotation marks or parentheses, these are accepted and retained as part of the option’s value.

arguments.name: MAPSSAS=
arguments.description: Specifies the location of the SAS library that contains SAS/GRAPH map data sets.

arguments.name: location-of-maps
arguments.description: specifies either a physical path, an environment variable, or the MAPSSAS libref to locate the SAS map data sets to use with SAS/GRAPH. The option value can consist of up to 2048 characters. Upper or lower case characters are accepted as entered. Though not required, if you specify start and end quotation marks or parentheses, these are accepted and retained as part of the option’s value.

arguments.name: MAXMEMQUERY
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum amount of memory that can be allocated per request for certain procedures.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the limit in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); or 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes. For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, a value of .782k specifies 801 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the limit in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); or 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes. For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, a value of .782k specifies 801 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the limit in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); or 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes. For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, a value of .782k specifies 801 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the limit in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); or 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes. For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, a value of .782k specifies 801 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory as a hexadecimal value. You must specify the value beginning with a number (0–9), followed by hexadecimal characters (0–9, A–F), and then followed by an X. For example, 2dx sets the amount of memory to 45 bytes.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: specifies 0 bytes, which indicates that there is no limit on the total amount of memory that can be allocated per request by each SAS procedure. These memory allocations are limited by the value of MEMSIZE.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: specifies a limit to the amount of memory that is allocated. Memory allocations (9,007,199,254,740,992 byte limit on 64-bit machines) are limited by the value of MEMSIZE.

arguments.name: MAXSEGRATIO=
arguments.description: Controls what percentage of index segments to identify as candidate segments before processing the WHERE expression. This occurs when evaluating a WHERE expression that contains indexed variables.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies an upper limit for the percentage of index segments that the SPD Engine identifies as containing the value referenced in the WHERE expression.

arguments.name: MERGENOBY=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of message that is issued when MERGE processing occurs without an associated BY statement.

arguments.name: NOWARN
arguments.description: specifies that no warning message is issued.

arguments.name: WARN
arguments.description: specifies that a warning message is issued.

arguments.name: ERROR
arguments.description: specifies that an error message is issued.

arguments.name: MISSING=
arguments.description: Specifies the character to print for missing numeric values.

arguments.name: character
arguments.description: specifies the value to be printed. The value can be any character. Single or double quotation marks are optional.

arguments.name: MSGLEVEL=
arguments.description: Specifies the level of detail in messages that are written to the SAS log.

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: specifies to print notes, warnings, CEDA message, and error messages only.

arguments.name: I
arguments.description: specifies to print additional notes that pertain to index usage, merge processing, sort utilities, data type conversion, execution in CAS, and Hadoop MapReduce jobs along with standard notes, warnings, CEDA messages, and error messages. The I argument prints additional information about running a DATA step and PROC COPY on the CAS server, and character conversion from VARCHAR to CHAR.

arguments.name: MSYMTABMAX
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum amount of memory available to the macro variable symbol tables.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the maximum amount of memory that is available in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); or 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes. For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, a value of .782k specifies 801 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the maximum amount of memory that is available in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); or 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes. For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, a value of .782k specifies 801 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the maximum amount of memory that is available in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); or 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes. For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, a value of .782k specifies 801 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the maximum amount of memory that is available in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); or 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes.
