For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, a value of .782k specifies 801 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the maximum amount of memory that is available as a hexadecimal value. You must specify the value beginning with a number (0–9), followed by hexadecimal characters (0–9, A–F), and then followed by an X. For example, 2dx sets the maximum amount of memory to 45 bytes.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: sets the amount of memory that is available to the minimum setting, which is 0 bytes. Setting the amount of memory to the minimum setting causes all macro symbol tables to be written to disk.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: sets the amount of memory that is available to the maximum setting. On 64-bit computers, this value is 9,007,199,254,740,992 bytes.

arguments.name: MULTENVAPPL
arguments.description: specifies that an application font selector window lists only the SAS fonts.

arguments.name: MVARSIZE
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum size for in-memory macro variables.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the maximum macro variable size in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); or 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes. For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, a value of .782k specifies 801 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the maximum macro variable size in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); or 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes. For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, a value of .782k specifies 801 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the maximum macro variable size in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); or 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes. For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, a value of .782k specifies 801 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the maximum macro variable size in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); or 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes. For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, a value of .782k specifies 801 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the maximum macro variable size as a hexadecimal value. You must specify the value beginning with a number (0–9), followed by hexadecimal characters (0–9, A–F), and then followed by an X. For example, 2dx sets the maximum macro variable size to 45 bytes.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: sets the macro variable size to the minimum setting, which is 0 bytes. Setting the macro variable size to the minimum setting causes all macro variable values to be written to disk.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: sets the macro variable size to the maximum setting, which is 65,534 bytes.

arguments.name: NLDECSEPARATOR
arguments.description: Enables locale-sensitive numeric output for the decimal separator.

arguments.name: NOACCESSIBLECHECK
arguments.description: specifies not to check for common violations of accessibility standards.

arguments.name: NOACCESSIBLEGRAPH
arguments.description: specifies not to enable the ACCESSIBLE_GRAPH option in the ODS HTML5 statement by default.

arguments.name: NOACCESSIBLEPDF
arguments.description: specifies not to enable the ACCESSIBLE option in the ODS PDF statement.

arguments.name: NOACCESSIBLETABLE
arguments.description: specifies not to create accessible tables by default.

arguments.name: NOANIMOVERLAY
arguments.description: specifies that each frame is played sequentially. When a frame is played, it replaces the previous frame.

arguments.name: NOAUTOCORRECT
arguments.description: specifies that SAS does not automatically attempt to correct misspelled procedure names, misspelled procedure keywords, or misspelled global statement names.

arguments.name: NOBOMFILE
arguments.description: Specifies not to write a BOM prefix when a Unicode-encoded file is written to an external file.

arguments.name: NOBYERR
arguments.description: specifies that SAS ignore the error message and continue processing if the SORT procedure attempts to sort a _NULL_ data.

arguments.name: NOBYLINE
arguments.description: suppresses the automatic printing of BY lines.

arguments.name: NOBYSORTED
arguments.description: specifies that observations with the same BY value are grouped together but are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

arguments.name: NOCAPS
arguments.description: specifies that lowercase characters that occur in the types of input that are listed above are not translated to uppercase.

arguments.name: NOCARDIMAGE
arguments.description: specifies that SAS source and data lines not be treated as if they were 80-byte card images. When NOCARDIMAGE is in effect, the end of a line is always treated as the end of the last token, except for strings in quotation marks. Strings in quotation marks can be split across lines. Other types of tokens cannot be split across lines under any circumstances. Strings in quotation marks that are split across lines are not padded with blanks.

arguments.name: NOCENTER
arguments.description: left aligns SAS procedure output.

arguments.name: NOCHARCODE
arguments.description: does not allow substitutions for certain keyboard characters.

arguments.name: NOCLEANUP
arguments.description: specifies that SAS allow the user to choose how to handle an out-of-resource condition. When NOCLEANUP is in effect and SAS cannot execute because of a lack of resources, SAS automatically attempts to clean up resources that are not visible to the user (for example, cache memory). However, resources that are visible to the user (for example, windows) are not automatically cleaned up. Instead, a dialog box appears that allows the user to choose how to proceed.

arguments.name: NOCMPOPT
arguments.description: specifies to set the value of CMPOPT to ALL. The compiler is to optimize the machine language code by using the (CONSTANTFOLDING NOEXTRAMATH NOMISSCHECK NOPRECISE NOFUNCDIFFERENCING SHORTCIRCUIT) optimization values.

arguments.name: NOCOLORPRINTING
arguments.description: specifies not to print in color.

arguments.name: NODATE
arguments.description: specifies that the date and the time are not printed.

arguments.name: NODBFMTIGNORE
arguments.description: specifies that numeric formats are used.

arguments.name: NODBIDIRECTEXEC
arguments.description: indicates that the SQL pass-through facility does not optimize handling of SQL statements.

arguments.name: NODEBUGOPT
arguments.description: Specifies the host and port where debugging SAS languages occurs

arguments.name: NODETAILS
arguments.description: does not include additional information.

arguments.name: NODLCREATEDIR
arguments.description: specifies not to create a directory for a SAS library that is named in a LIBNAME statement.

arguments.name: NODSNFERR
arguments.description: specifies that SAS ignore the error message and continue processing if a reference is made to a SAS data set that does not exist. The data set reference is treated as if _NULL_ had been specified.

arguments.name: NODTRESET
arguments.description: specifies that SAS not update the date and time in the titles of the SAS log and the procedure output file.

arguments.name: NOECHOAUTO
arguments.description: specifies that SAS statements in the AUTOEXEC= file are not written in the SAS log, even though they are executed.

arguments.name: NOEMAILFROM
arguments.description: specifies that the FROM email option is not required when sending email by using either the FILE or FILENAME statements.

arguments.name: NOERRORABEND
arguments.description: specifies that SAS handle errors normally, that is, issue an error message, set OBS=0, and go into syntax-check mode (if syntax checking is enabled).

arguments.name: NOERRORBYABEND
arguments.description: specifies that SAS handle BY-group errors normally, that is, by issuing an error message and continuing processing.

arguments.name: NOFMTERR
arguments.description: replaces missing formats with the w. or $w. default format, issues a note, and continues processing.

arguments.name: NOFONTEMBEDDING
arguments.description: specifies to disable font embedding.

arguments.name: NOFULLSTIMER
arguments.description: does not write to the SAS log a complete list of resources or a datetime stamp.

arguments.name: NOHOSTINFOLONG
arguments.description: specifies to omit additional operating environment information in the SAS log when SAS starts.

arguments.name: NOLABEL
arguments.description: specifies that SAS procedures cannot use labels with variables. If NOLABEL is specified, the LABEL option of a procedure is ignored.

arguments.name: NOMULTENVAPPL
arguments.description: specifies that an application font selector window lists only the operating environment fonts.

arguments.name: NONLDECSEPARATOR
arguments.description: Disables locale-sensitive numeric output for the decimal separator.

arguments.name: NONOTES
arguments.description: specifies that SAS not write notes to the SAS log. NONOTES does not suppress error and warning messages.

arguments.name: NONUMBER
arguments.description: specifies that SAS not print the page number on the first title line of each page of SAS output.

arguments.name: NOOVP
arguments.description: specifies that overprinting of error messages is disabled.

arguments.name: NOPAGEBREAKINITIAL
arguments.description: specifies not to begin the SAS log and procedure output files on a new page.

arguments.name: NOPDFACCESS
arguments.description: specifies that PDF documents cannot be edited.

arguments.name: NOPDFASSEMBLY
arguments.description: specifies that PDF documents cannot be assembled.

arguments.name: NOPDFCOMMENT
arguments.description: specifies that PDF document comments cannot be modified.

arguments.name: NOPDFCONTENT
arguments.description: specifies that the contents of a PDF document cannot be changed.

arguments.name: NOPDFCOPY
arguments.description: specifies that text and graphics from a PDF document cannot be copied.

arguments.name: NOPDFFILLIN
arguments.description: specifies that PDF forms cannot be filled in.

arguments.name: NOPRINTMSGLIST
arguments.description: specifies to print only the top-level message to the SAS log.

arguments.name: NOQUOTELENMAX
arguments.description: specifies that SAS does not write a note to the SAS log about the maximum length for strings in quotation marks.

arguments.name: NOREPLACE
arguments.description: specifies that a permanently stored SAS data set cannot be replaced with another SAS data set, which prevents the accidental replacement of existing SAS data sets.

arguments.name: NORSASIOTRANSERROR
arguments.description: specifies not to display a transcoding error when invalid values are read from a remote application.

arguments.name: NOSASAUTOS
arguments.description: The NOSASAUTOS option causes SAS to ignore all previous SASAUTOS specifications (whether specified in the configuration file or in the SASV9_OPTIONS environment variable).

arguments.name: NOSORTEQUALS
arguments.description: specifies that no resources be used to control the order of observations with identical BY variable values in the output data set.

arguments.name: NOSORTVALIDATE
arguments.description: specifies that the SORT procedure is not to verify if the observations in the data set are sorted.

arguments.name: NOSOURCE
arguments.description: does not write SAS source statements to the SAS log.

arguments.name: NOSOURCE2
arguments.description: does not write secondary source statements to the SAS log.

arguments.name: NOSPOOL
arguments.description: specifies that SAS does not write statements to a utility data set. Specifying NOSPOOL accelerates execution time, but you cannot use the %INCLUDE and %LIST statements to resubmit SAS statements that were executed earlier in the session.

arguments.name: NOSQLCONSTDATETIME
arguments.description: specifies that the SQL procedure is not to replace references to the DATE, TIME, DATETIME, and TODAY functions with their equivalent numeric constant values.

arguments.name: SQLCONSTDATETIME
arguments.description: specifies that the SQL procedure is to replace references to the DATE, TIME, DATETIME, and TODAY functions with their equivalent numeric constant values.

arguments.name: NOSQLIPONEATTEMPT
arguments.description: has no limitations on how many times PROC SQL can reject a query or part of a query that is being sent to a DBMS. This is the default value.

arguments.name: SQLIPONEATTEMPT
arguments.description: instructs PROC SQL to fail an implicit pass-through (IP) query if the DBMS that the query or part of the query is being sent to rejects it.

arguments.name: NOSQLREMERGE
arguments.description: specifies that PROC SQL cannot process queries that use remerged data.

arguments.name: SQLREMERGE
arguments.description: specifies that PROC SQL can process queries that use remerged data.

arguments.name: NOSTIMER
arguments.description: does not write any statistics to the SAS log.

arguments.name: NOSVGAUTOPLAY
arguments.description: specifies to display the first frame of the animation in the web page. The animated file is started by clicking Animation Play button.

arguments.name: NOSVGCONTROLBUTTONS
arguments.description: specifies not to display the paging control buttons in the SVG document.

arguments.name: NOSVGMAGNIFYBUTTON
arguments.description: specifies to disable the SVG magnify tool for all SVG documents.

arguments.name: NOSYNTAXCHECK
arguments.description: does not enable syntax check mode for statements that are submitted within a non-interactive or batch SAS session.

arguments.name: NOTES
arguments.description: specifies that SAS write notes to the SAS log.

arguments.name: NOTHREADS
arguments.description: specifies not to use threaded processing for running SAS applications that support it.

arguments.name: NOUPRINTCOMPRESSION
arguments.description: specifies to disable compression of files created by some Universal Printers and some SAS/GRAPH devices.

arguments.name: NOVNFERR
arguments.description: specifies that SAS issue a warning when a BY variable exists in one data set but not in another data set when the other data set is _NULL_. This option applies when processing the SET, MERGE, UPDATE, or MODIFY statements. When the warning occurs, SAS does not enter into syntax-check mode.

arguments.name: VNFERR
arguments.description: specifies that SAS issue an error when a BY variable exists in one data set but not in another data set when the other data set is _NULL_. This option applies when processing the SET, MERGE, UPDATE, or MODIFY statements. When the error occurs, SAS enters into syntax-check mode.

arguments.name: NOWORKTERM
arguments.description: does not erase the Work files.

arguments.name: NOXCMD
arguments.description: specifies that the X command is not valid in the current SAS session.

arguments.name: NUMBER
arguments.description: specifies that SAS print the page number on the first title line of each page of SAS output.

arguments.name: OBS=
arguments.description: Specifies the observation that is used to determine the last observation to process, or specifies the last record to process.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies a number to indicate when to stop processing, where n is an integer. Using one of the letter notations results in multiplying the integer by a specific value. That is, specifying K (kilo) multiplies the integer by 1,024; M (mega) multiplies by 1,048,576; G (giga) multiplies by 1,073,741,824; or T (tera) multiplies by 1,099,511,627,776. For example, a value of 20 specifies 20 observations or records, whereas a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 observations or records.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies a number to indicate when to stop processing, where n is an integer. Using one of the letter notations results in multiplying the integer by a specific value. That is, specifying K (kilo) multiplies the integer by 1,024; M (mega) multiplies by 1,048,576; G (giga) multiplies by 1,073,741,824; or T (tera) multiplies by 1,099,511,627,776. For example, a value of 20 specifies 20 observations or records, whereas a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 observations or records.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies a number to indicate when to stop processing, where n is an integer. Using one of the letter notations results in multiplying the integer by a specific value. That is, specifying K (kilo) multiplies the integer by 1,024; M (mega) multiplies by 1,048,576; G (giga) multiplies by 1,073,741,824; or T (tera) multiplies by 1,099,511,627,776. For example, a value of 20 specifies 20 observations or records, whereas a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 observations or records.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies a number to indicate when to stop processing, where n is an integer. Using one of the letter notations results in multiplying the integer by a specific value. That is, specifying K (kilo) multiplies the integer by 1,024; M (mega) multiplies by 1,048,576; G (giga) multiplies by 1,073,741,824; or T (tera) multiplies by 1,099,511,627,776. For example, a value of 20 specifies 20 observations or records, whereas a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 observations or records.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: specifies a number to indicate when to stop processing, where n is an integer. Using one of the letter notations results in multiplying the integer by a specific value. That is, specifying K (kilo) multiplies the integer by 1,024; M (mega) multiplies by 1,048,576; G (giga) multiplies by 1,073,741,824; or T (tera) multiplies by 1,099,511,627,776. For example, a value of 20 specifies 20 observations or records, whereas a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 observations or records.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies a number to indicate when to stop processing as a hexadecimal value. The value must begin with a number (0–9) and must be followed by an X. For example, the hexadecimal value F8 must be specified as 0F8x in order to specify the decimal equivalent of 248. The value 2dx specifies the decimal equivalent of 45.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: sets the number to 0 to indicate when to stop processing.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: sets the number to indicate when to stop processing to the maximum number of observations or records, up to the largest eight-byte, signed integer, which is 263-1, or approximately 9.2 quintillion.

arguments.name: ORIENTATION=
arguments.description: Specifies the paper orientation to use when printing to a printer.

arguments.name: PORTRAIT
arguments.description: specifies the paper orientation as portrait.

arguments.name: LANDSCAPE
arguments.description: specifies the paper orientation as landscape.

arguments.name: REVERSEPORTRAIT
arguments.description: specifies the paper orientation as reverse portrait. Use this value to control the top of the page relative to how the paper is inserted into the input paper tray. REVERSEPORTRAIT can be used when you print preprinted or punched forms.

arguments.name: REVERSELANDSCAPE
arguments.description: specifies the paper orientation as reverse landscape. Use this value to control the top of the page relative to how the paper is inserted into the input paper tray. REVERSELANDSCAPE can be used when you print preprinted or punched forms.

arguments.name: OVP
arguments.description: specifies that overprinting of error messages is enabled.

arguments.name: PAGEBREAKINITIAL
arguments.description: specifies to begin the SAS log and procedure output files on a new page.

arguments.name: PAGENO=
arguments.description: Resets the SAS output page number.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the page number in multiples of 1 (n); 1,024 (nK). For example, a value of 8 sets the page number to 8 and a value of 3k sets the page number to 3,072.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the page number in multiples of 1 (n); 1,024 (nK). For example, a value of 8 sets the page number to 8 and a value of 3k sets the page number to 3,072.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the page number as a hexadecimal number. The value must begin with a number (0–9) and must be followed by an X. For example, the value 2dx sets the page number to 45.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: sets the page number to the minimum number, 1.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: specifies the maximum page number as the largest signed, four–byte integer that is representable in your operating environment.

arguments.name: PAGESIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of lines that compose a page of the SAS log and SAS output.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the number of lines that compose a page in multiples of 1 (n) or 1,024 (nK). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes. For example, a value of 800 specifies 800 lines, a value of .782k specifies 801 lines, and a value of 3k specifies 3,072 lines.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the number of lines that compose a page in multiples of 1 (n) or 1,024 (nK). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes. For example, a value of 800 specifies 800 lines, a value of .782k specifies 801 lines, and a value of 3k specifies 3,072 lines.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the number of lines that compose a page as a hexadecimal number. The value must begin with a number (0–9) and must be followed by an X. For example, the value 2dx sets the number of lines that compose a page to 45.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: sets the number of lines that compose a page to the minimum setting, 15.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: sets the number of lines that compose a page to the maximum setting, 32,767.

arguments.name: PAPERSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the paper size to use for printing.

arguments.name: LOCALE
arguments.description: specifies to use the value of the LOCALE= system option to determine the value of the PAPERSIZE= option. Depending on the locale, the PAPERSIZE= option is set to either LETTER or A4.

arguments.name: paper_size_name
arguments.description: specifies a predefined paper size.

arguments.name: (“width-value”, “height-value”)
arguments.description: specifies paper width and height as positive floating-point values.

arguments.name: PARM=
arguments.description: Specifies a parameter string that is passed to an external program.

arguments.name: string
arguments.description: specifies a character string that contains a parameter.

arguments.name: PARMCARDS=
arguments.description: Specifies the file reference to open when SAS encounters the PARMCARDS statement in a procedure.

arguments.name: file-ref
arguments.description: specifies the file reference to open.

arguments.name: PDFACCESS
arguments.description: specifies that PDF documents can be edited.

arguments.name: PDFASSEMBLY
arguments.description: specifies that PDF documents can be assembled.

arguments.name: PDFCOMMENT
arguments.description: specifies that PDF document comments can be modified.

arguments.name: PDFCONTENT
arguments.description: specifies that the contents of a PDF document can be changed.

arguments.name: PDFCOPY
arguments.description: specifies that text and graphics from a PDF document can be copied.

arguments.name: PDFFILLIN
arguments.description: specifies that PDF forms can be filled in.

arguments.name: PDFPAGELAYOUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the page layout for PDF documents.
arguments.help:
PDFPAGELAYOUT=  DEFAULT | SINGLEPAGE | CONTINUOUS | 
	FACING | CONTINUOUSFACING

arguments.name: DEFAULT
arguments.description: specifies to use the current page layout for Acrobat Reader.

arguments.name: SINGLEPAGE
arguments.description: specifies to display one page at a time in the viewing area.

arguments.name: CONTINUOUS
arguments.description: specifies to display all document pages in the viewing area in a single column.

arguments.name: FACING
arguments.description: specifies to display only two pages in the viewing area, with the even pages on the left and the odd pages on the right.

arguments.name: CONTINUOUSFACING
arguments.description: specifies to display all pages in the viewing area, two pages side by side. The even pages are displayed on the left, and the odd pages display on the right.

arguments.name: PDFPAGEVIEW=
arguments.description: Specifies the page viewing mode for PDF documents.
arguments.help: PDFPAGEVIEW=  DEFAULT | ACTUAL | FITPAGE | FITWIDTH | FULLSCREEN

arguments.name: DEFAULT
arguments.description: specifies to use the current page view setting for Acrobat Reader.

arguments.name: ACTUAL
arguments.description: specifies to set the page view setting to 100%.

arguments.name: FITPAGE
arguments.description: specifies to view a page using the full extent of the viewing window, maintaining the height and width aspect ratio.

arguments.name: FITWIDTH
arguments.description: specifies to view a page using the full width of the viewing window. The height of the document is not scaled to fit the page.

arguments.name: FULLSCREEN
arguments.description: specifies to view a page using the full screen. This option disables the table of contents, bookmarks, and all other document access aids, such as accessing a specific page.

arguments.name: PDFPRINT=
arguments.description: Specifies the resolution to print PDF documents.

arguments.name: HRES
arguments.description: specifies to print PDF documents at the highest resolution available on the printer.

arguments.name: LRES
arguments.description: specifies to print PDF documents at a lower resolution for draft-quality documents.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: specifies the PDF documents have no print resolution.

arguments.name: PDFSECURITY=
arguments.description: Specifies the level of encryption for PDF documents.

arguments.name: HIGH
arguments.description: specifies that SAS encrypts PDF documents using a 128-bit encryption algorithm.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: specifies that no encryption is performed on PDF documents.

arguments.name: PRINTCMD
arguments.description: Specifies the print command that SAS uses.

arguments.name: print-command
arguments.description: specifies the options that you can use with PRINTCMD.

arguments.name: PRINTERPATH=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of a registered printer to use for Universal Printing.

arguments.name: 'printer-name'
arguments.description: must be one of the printers defined in the SAS Registry

arguments.name: PRINTMSGLIST
arguments.description: specifies to print the entire list of messages to the SAS log.

arguments.name: QUOTELENMAX
arguments.description: specifies that SAS write a note to the SAS log about the maximum length for strings in quotation marks.

arguments.name: REPLACE
arguments.description: specifies that a permanently stored SAS data set can be replaced with another SAS data set.

arguments.name: REUSE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether SAS reuses space when observations are added to a compressed SAS data set.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies to track free space and reuses it whenever observations are added to an existing compressed data set.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies not to track free space.

arguments.name: RIGHTMARGIN=
arguments.description: Specifies the print margin for the right side of the page.

arguments.name: margin-size
arguments.description: specifies the size of the margin.

arguments.name: <margin-unit>
arguments.description: specifies the units for margin-size. The margin-unit can be in for inches or cm for centimeters. <margin-unit> is saved as part of the value of the RIGHTMARGIN system option.

arguments.name: RSASIOTRANSERROR
arguments.description: specifies to display a transcoding error when invalid values are read from a remote application.

arguments.name: RTRACELOC
arguments.description: Specifies the pathname of the file to which the list of resources that are read or loaded during a SAS session is written.

arguments.name: pathname
arguments.description: specifies the file to which RTRACE information is written. The pathname must include the path and the filename for the RTRACE output.

arguments.name: S2=
arguments.description: Specifies the length of statements on each line of a source statement from a %INCLUDE statement, an AUTOEXEC= file, or an autocall macro file.

arguments.name: S
arguments.description: uses the current value of the S= system option to compute the record length of text that comes from a %INCLUDE statement, an AUTOEXEC= file, or an autocall macro file.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the length of the statements in a file that is specified in a %INCLUDE statement, an autoexec file, or an autocall macro file, in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the length of the statements in a file that is specified in a %INCLUDE statement, an autoexec file, or an autocall macro file, in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the length of the statements in a file that is specified in a %INCLUDE statement, an autoexec file, or an autocall macro file, in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the length of the statements in a file that is specified in a %INCLUDE statement, an autoexec file, or an autocall macro file, in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: specifies the length of the statements in a file that is specified in a %INCLUDE statement, an autoexec file, or an autocall macro file, in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the length of statements as a hexadecimal number. The value must begin with a number (0–9) and must be followed by an X. For example, the value 2dx sets the length of statements to 45.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: sets the length of statements and data to 0.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: sets the length of statements and data to 2,147,483,647.

arguments.name: S2V=
arguments.description: Specifies the starting position to begin reading a file that is specified in a %INCLUDE statement, an autoexec file, or an autocall macro file with a variable length record format.

arguments.name: S2
arguments.description: specifies to use the current value of the S2= system option to compute the starting position of the variable-sized record to read from a %INCLUDE statement, an autoexec file, or an autocall macro file. This is the default. The S2= option has a default value of 0.

arguments.name: S
arguments.description: specifies to use the current value of the S= system option to compute the starting position of the variable-sized record to read from a %INCLUDE statement, an autoexec file, or an autocall macro file.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the starting position of the variable-length record to read that comes from a %INCLUDE statement, an autoexec file, or an autocall macro file, in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the starting position of the variable-length record to read that comes from a %INCLUDE statement, an autoexec file, or an autocall macro file, in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the starting position of the variable-length record to read that comes from a %INCLUDE statement, an autoexec file, or an autocall macro file, in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the starting position of the variable-length record to read that comes from a %INCLUDE statement, an autoexec file, or an autocall macro file, in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: specifies the starting position of the variable-length record to read that comes from a %INCLUDE statement, an autoexec file, or an autocall macro file, in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: sets the starting position of the variable-length record to read that comes from a %INCLUDE statement, an autoexec file, or an autocall macro, to 0.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: sets the starting position of the variable-length record to read that comes from a %INCLUDE statement, an autoexec file, or an autocall macro, to 2,147,483,647.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the starting position of the variable-length record to read that comes from a %INCLUDE statement, an autoexec file, or an autocall macro, as a hexadecimal number. The value must begin with a number (0–9) and must be followed by an X.

arguments.name: S=
arguments.description: Specifies the length of statements on each line of a source statement and the length of data on lines that follow a DATALINES statement.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the length of statements and data in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the length of statements and data in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the length of statements and data in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the length of statements and data in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: specifies the length of statements and data in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the length of statements and data as a hexadecimal number. The value must begin with a number (0–9) and must be followed by an X. For example, the value 2dx sets the length of statements and data to 45.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: sets the length of statements and data to 0.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: sets the length of statements and data to 2,147,483,647.

arguments.name: SASAUTOS
arguments.description: Specifies the autocall library.

arguments.name: directory-specification
arguments.description: specifies a pathname to an autocall macro library.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: specifies a name (shorthand reference) that has been assigned to an autocall macro library.

arguments.name: SASTRACE=
arguments.description: Generates trace information from a DBMS engine.

arguments.name: ',,,d'
arguments.description: specifies that all SQL statements that are sent to the DBMS are sent to the log. Here are the applicable statements:

arguments.name: ',,d,'
arguments.description: specifies that all routine calls are sent to the log. All function enters, exits, and pertinent parameters and return codes are traced when you select this option. The information varies from engine to engine, however.

arguments.name: 'd,'
arguments.description: specifies that all DBMS calls (such as API and client calls, connection information, column bindings, column error information, and row processing) are sent to the log. This information varies from engine to engine, however.

arguments.name: 'd,,,'
arguments.description: specifies that version information for the current DBMS and client are displayed in the log.

arguments.name: ',,,db'
arguments.description: specifies that only a brief version of all SQL statements that the ',,,d' option normally generates are sent to the log.

arguments.name: ',,,s'
arguments.description: specifies that a summary of timing information for calls made to the DBMS is sent to the log.

arguments.name: ',,,sa'
arguments.description: specifies that timing information for each call that is made to the DBMS is sent to the log along with a summary.

arguments.name: ',,t,'
arguments.description:
specifies that all threading information is sent to the log. Here is the information that it includes:
• number of threads that are spawned
• number of observations that each thread contains
• exit code of the thread, if it fails

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: specifies to turn tracing off.

arguments.name: SASTRACELOC=
arguments.description: Specifies the location where SASTRACE= information should be printed.

arguments.name: stdout
arguments.description: specifies the default output location for your operating environment.

arguments.name: SASLOG
arguments.description: specifies that trace messages should be printed to the SAS log.

arguments.name: FILE=
arguments.description: specifies that trace messages should be printed to a file name that you provide. If you do not provide a path, the file is generated in the current working directory.

arguments.name: SEQ=
arguments.description: Specifies the length of the numeric portion of the sequence field in input source lines or data lines.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the length in terms of bytes.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: sets the minimum length to 1.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: sets the maximum length to 8.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the length as a hexadecimal. The value must begin with a number (0–9) and must be followed by an X.

arguments.name: SESSREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of the default CAS session to use if a statement or procedure does not explicitly identify a session reference name.

arguments.name: SET
arguments.description: Defines a SAS environment variable for a SAS Session.

arguments.name: SORTANOM
arguments.description: Specifies options for the host sort utility.

arguments.name: B
arguments.description: tells SyncSort to run in multi-call mode, instead of single-call mode. (See the documentation for syncsort for more information.)

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: writes to the SAS log statistics about the external sorting process.

arguments.name: V
arguments.description: writes to the SAS log all of the commands that are passed to the host sort utility.

arguments.name: SORTCUT
arguments.description: Specifies the data size in number of observations above which SAS uses the host sort instead of the internal SAS sort.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the number of observations in multiples of 1 (n); 1,024 (nK); 1,048,576 (nM); or 1,073,741,824 (nG). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes. For example, a value of 800 specifies 800 observations, a value of .782k specifies 801 observations, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 observations.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the number of observations in multiples of 1 (n); 1,024 (nK); 1,048,576 (nM); or 1,073,741,824 (nG). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes. For example, a value of 800 specifies 800 observations, a value of .782k specifies 801 observations, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 observations.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the number of observations in multiples of 1 (n); 1,024 (nK); 1,048,576 (nM); or 1,073,741,824 (nG). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes. For example, a value of 800 specifies 800 observations, a value of .782k specifies 801 observations, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 observations.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the number of observations in multiples of 1 (n); 1,024 (nK); 1,048,576 (nM); or 1,073,741,824 (nG). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes. For example, a value of 800 specifies 800 observations, a value of .782k specifies 801 observations, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 observations.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the number of observations as a hexadecimal value. You must specify the value beginning with a number (0–9), followed by hexadecimal characters (0–9, A–F), and then followed by an X. For example, the value 2ffx specifies 767 observations.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: specifies 0 observations.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: specifies 9,007,199,254,740,992 observations.

arguments.name: SORTCUTP
arguments.description: Specifies the data size in bytes above which SAS uses the host sort instead of the internal SAS sort.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the number of bytes in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); or 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes. For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, a value of .782k specifies 801 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the number of bytes in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); or 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes. For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, a value of .782k specifies 801 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the number of bytes in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); or 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes. For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, a value of .782k specifies 801 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the number of bytes in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); or 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). You can specify decimal values for the number of kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes. For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, a value of .782k specifies 801 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the number of bytes as a hexadecimal value. You must specify the value beginning with a number (0–9), followed by hexadecimal characters (0–9, A–F), and then followed by an X. For example, the value 2dx specifies 45 bytes.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: specifies 0 bytes.

arguments.name: SORTDEV
arguments.description: Specifies the pathname used for temporary files created by the host sort utility.

arguments.name: SORTEQUALS
arguments.description: specifies that observations with identical BY variable values are to retain the same relative positions in the output data set as in the input data set.

arguments.name: SORTNAME
arguments.description: Specifies the name of the host sort utility.

arguments.name: SORTPARM
arguments.description: Specifies parameters for the host sort utility.

arguments.name: parameter
arguments.description: specifies any parameter that you want to pass to the sort utility. For a description of these parameters, see the documentation for the sort that you are using.

arguments.name: SORTPGM
arguments.description: Specifies whether to use the internal SAS sort utility or the host sort utility or to let SAS choose which sort utility to use.

arguments.name: SAS
arguments.description: tells SAS to use the SAS sort.

arguments.name: HOST
arguments.description: tells SAS to use the sort that is specified by the SORTNAME system option.

arguments.name: BEST
arguments.description:
tells SAS to use the best routine to sort the data set: the SAS sort or the host sort that is specified by the SORTNAME system option. When set, the settings of the SORTCUT and SORTCUTP system options determine whether SAS chooses the SAS sort or the host sort. When SORTCUT and SORTCUTP are not set (or when they are both 0), SAS selects the sorting algorithm based on the following order of precedence:
• host sort utility
• SAS sort utility

arguments.name: SORTSEQ=
arguments.description: Specifies a language-specific collating sequence for the SORT and SQL procedures to use in the current SAS session.

arguments.name: sort-table
arguments.description: specifies a translation table that you created with PROC TRANTAB.

arguments.name: LINGUISTIC
arguments.description: Sorts characters according to the rules of a specified language. The rules and default collating sequence are based on the language specified in the current locale setting. The implementation is provided by the International Components for Unicode (ICU) library. Refer to for more information.

arguments.name: SORTSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the amount of memory that is available to the SORT procedure.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory in terms of 1 (byte); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 4000 specifies 4,000 bytes and a value of 2m specifies 2,097,152 bytes. If n=0, the sort utility uses its default. Valid values for SORTSIZE range from 0 to 9,223,372,036,854,775,807.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory in terms of 1 (byte); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 4000 specifies 4,000 bytes and a value of 2m specifies 2,097,152 bytes. If n=0, the sort utility uses its default. Valid values for SORTSIZE range from 0 to 9,223,372,036,854,775,807.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory in terms of 1 (byte); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 4000 specifies 4,000 bytes and a value of 2m specifies 2,097,152 bytes. If n=0, the sort utility uses its default. Valid values for SORTSIZE range from 0 to 9,223,372,036,854,775,807.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory in terms of 1 (byte); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 4000 specifies 4,000 bytes and a value of 2m specifies 2,097,152 bytes. If n=0, the sort utility uses its default. Valid values for SORTSIZE range from 0 to 9,223,372,036,854,775,807.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory in terms of 1 (byte); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 4000 specifies 4,000 bytes and a value of 2m specifies 2,097,152 bytes. If n=0, the sort utility uses its default. Valid values for SORTSIZE range from 0 to 9,223,372,036,854,775,807.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory as a hexadecimal number. The value must begin with a number (0–9) and must be followed by an X. For example, 0fffx specifies 4,095 bytes of memory.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: specifies 0 bytes, which indicates that there is no limit except the limitation specified by the MEMSIZE system option.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: specifies the maximum amount of memory available.

arguments.name: SORTVALIDATE
arguments.description: specifies that the SORT procedure verifies if the observations in the data set are sorted by the variables specified in the BY statement.

arguments.name: SOUNDSLIKELEN=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of bytes used by the sounds-like operator.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the length that is used to compare results of the SOUNDEX function when performing the sounds-like operation. If n < 0, all characters of the results of the SOUNDEX function are compared. The length can be specified in multiples of 1 (n) or 1,024 (nK). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, a value of .782k specifies 801 bytes, and a value of 3k specifies 3,072 bytes.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the length that is used to compare results of the SOUNDEX function when performing the sounds-like operation. If n < 0, all characters of the results of the SOUNDEX function are compared. The length can be specified in multiples of 1 (n) or 1,024 (nK). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, a value of .782k specifies 801 bytes, and a value of 3k specifies 3,072 bytes.

arguments.name: SOURCE
arguments.description: writes SAS source statements to the SAS log.

arguments.name: SOURCE2
arguments.description: writes source statements from files that have been included by %INCLUDE statements or autocall macros to the SAS log.

arguments.name: SPDEINDEXSORTSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the memory space size that the sorting utility can use when sorting values for creating an index.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: is the size of memory space in bytes, kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes.

arguments.name: SPDEPARALLELREAD=
arguments.description: Determines when the SPD Engine uses parallel processing to read data stored in HDFS.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that parallel processing occurs only if a Read operation includes WHERE processing. This is the default behavior for the SPD Engine.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: requests parallel processing for all Read operations for the SAS session.

arguments.name: SPDESORTSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the memory space size that is needed for sorting operations used by the SPD Engine.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: is the size of memory space in bytes, kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes.

arguments.name: SPDEWHEVAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the process to determine which observations meet the condition or conditions of a WHERE expression.

arguments.name: COST
arguments.description: specifies that the SPD Engine decides which evaluation strategy to use to optimize the WHERE expression. This process calculates the number of threads to be used, which minimizes the overhead of spawning underused threads. This is the default.

arguments.name: EVAL1
arguments.description: is a multi-threaded index evaluation strategy that can quickly determine the rows that satisfy the WHERE expression using multiple threads. The number of threads that are spawned to retrieve the observations is equal to the THREADNUM= value.

arguments.name: EVAL3EVAL4
arguments.description: is a single-threaded index evaluation strategy that is used for a simple or compound WHERE expression. All the key variables have a simple index and no condition tests for non-equality. Multi-threading might be used to retrieve the observations.

arguments.name: SPOOL
arguments.description: specifies that SAS write statements to a utility data set in the Work library for later use by a %INCLUDE or %LIST statement, or by the RECALL command, within a windowing environment.

arguments.name: SQLCONSTDATETIME
arguments.description: specifies that the SQL procedure is to replace references to the DATE, TIME, DATETIME, and TODAY functions with their equivalent numeric constant values.

arguments.name: NOSQLCONSTDATETIME
arguments.description: specifies that the SQL procedure is not to replace references to the DATE, TIME, DATETIME, and TODAY functions with their equivalent numeric constant values.

arguments.name: SQLGENERATION=
arguments.description: Specifies whether and when SAS procedures generate SQL for in-database processing of source data.

arguments.name: DBMS=
arguments.description: specifies one or more SAS/ACCESS engines. It modifies the primary state.

arguments.name: EXCLUDEDB=
arguments.description: prevents SAS procedures from generating SQL for in-database processing for one or more specified SAS/ACCESS engines.

arguments.name: EXCLUDEPROC=
arguments.description: prevents one or more specified SAS procedures from generating SQL for in-database processing for one or more specified SAS/ACCESS engines.

arguments.name: SQLIPONEATTEMPT
arguments.description: instructs PROC SQL to fail an implicit pass-through (IP) query if the DBMS that the query or part of the query is being sent to rejects it.

arguments.name: NOSQLIPONEATTEMPT
arguments.description: has no limitations on how many times PROC SQL can reject a query or part of a query that is being sent to a DBMS. This is the default value.

arguments.name: SQLMAPPUTTO=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the PUT function is mapped to the SAS_PUT function for a database. Use this system option to specify an alternative database in which the SAS_PUT function is published.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: specifies to PROC SQL that no PUT function mapping is to occur.

arguments.name: SAS_PUT
arguments.description: specifies that the PUT function be mapped to the SAS_PUT function in the database.

arguments.name: .SAS_PUT
arguments.description: specifies the database name where the SAS_PUT function and format definitions reside.

arguments.name: SQLREDUCEPUT=
arguments.description: For the SQL procedure, specifies the engine type to use to optimize a PUT function in a query. The PUT function is replaced with a logically equivalent expression.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: specifies to consider the optimization of all PUT functions, regardless of the engine that is used by the query to access the data.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: specifies to not optimize any PUT function.

arguments.name: DBMS
arguments.description: specifies to consider the optimization of all PUT functions in a query performed by a SAS/ACCESS engine. This is the default.

arguments.name: BASE
arguments.description: specifies to consider the optimization of all PUT functions in a query performed by a SAS/ACCESS engine or a Base SAS engine.

arguments.name: SQLREDUCEPUTOBS=
arguments.description: For the SQL procedure, when the SQLREDUCEPUT= system option is set to DBMS, BASE, or ALL, specifies the minimum number of observations that must be in a table for PROC SQL to optimize the PUT function in a query.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the minimum number of observations that must be in a table for PROC SQL to optimize the PUT function in a query.

arguments.name: SQLREDUCEPUTVALUES=
arguments.description: For the SQL procedure, when the SQLREDUCEPUT= system option is set to DBMS, BASE, or ALL, specifies the maximum number of SAS format values that can exist in a PUT function expression for PROC SQL to optimize the PUT function in a query.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of SAS format values that can exist in a PUT function expression for PROC SQL to optimize the PUT function in a query.

arguments.name: SQLREMERGE
arguments.description: specifies that PROC SQL can process queries that use remerged data.

arguments.name: NOSQLREMERGE
arguments.description: specifies that PROC SQL cannot process queries that use remerged data.

arguments.name: SQLUNDOPOLICY
arguments.description: Specifies how PROC SQL handles updated data if errors occur while you are updating data. You can use UNDO_POLICY= to control whether your changes are permanent.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: keeps any updates or inserts.

arguments.name: OPTIONAL
arguments.description: reverses any updates or inserts that it can reverse reliably.

arguments.name: REQUIRED
arguments.description: reverses all updates or inserts that have been made up to the point of the error. This is the default.

arguments.name: SQL_PUSHTCINTOVIEW_FROM_OUTSIDE
arguments.description: Specifies that a truncated comparison operator (=:) in a WHERE clause returns all of the values in a view that begin with the specified value.

arguments.name: NON
arguments.description: Specifies that the =: operator in a WHERE clause is not applied to a view.

arguments.name: STIMEFMT
arguments.description: Specifies the format that is used to display the time on FULLSTIMER and STIMER output.

arguments.name: Memory
arguments.description: is normally displayed as part of FULLSTIMER. The default memory output is displayed in kilobytes. The following options for memory are available:

arguments.name: Elapsed
arguments.description: can be configured to display hours, minutes, seconds, or best fit in STIMER and FULLSTIMER.

arguments.name: Counters
arguments.description: specifies that additional counters can be displayed as part of FULLSTIMER.

arguments.name: Help
arguments.description: provides two values that are used to access help for the STIMEFMT option:

arguments.name: STIMER
arguments.description: writes only real time and CPU time to the SAS log.

arguments.name: STRIPESIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies one or more directory and size argument pairs that set the size of SAS data sets and utility files in that directory to the size of an I/O device stripe.

arguments.name: directory-path
arguments.description: specifies an existing directory where the I/O page size for SAS data sets and utility files that are created in this directory is set to size. Subdirectories of directory-path inherit the data set or utility file size unless the STRIPESIZE= option has been set for the subdirectory.

arguments.name: size
arguments.description: specifies the number of bytes in a RAID (Redundant Array of Independent Disks) stripe, in multiples of 1: 1,024 (kilo); 1,048,576 (mega); 1,073,741,824 (giga). For example, a value of 1024 specifies 1,024 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: SUMSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies a limit on the amount of memory that is available for data summarization procedures when class variables are active.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). When n=0, the default value, the amount of memory is determined by values of the MEMSIZE option and the REALMEMSIZE option. Valid values for SUMSIZE range from 0 to 2 (n-1) where n is the data width in bits (32 or 64) of the operating system.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). When n=0, the default value, the amount of memory is determined by values of the MEMSIZE option and the REALMEMSIZE option. Valid values for SUMSIZE range from 0 to 2 (n-1) where n is the data width in bits (32 or 64) of the operating system.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). When n=0, the default value, the amount of memory is determined by values of the MEMSIZE option and the REALMEMSIZE option. Valid values for SUMSIZE range from 0 to 2 (n-1) where n is the data width in bits (32 or 64) of the operating system.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). When n=0, the default value, the amount of memory is determined by values of the MEMSIZE option and the REALMEMSIZE option. Valid values for SUMSIZE range from 0 to 2 (n-1) where n is the data width in bits (32 or 64) of the operating system.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory in terms of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). When n=0, the default value, the amount of memory is determined by values of the MEMSIZE option and the REALMEMSIZE option. Valid values for SUMSIZE range from 0 to 2 (n-1) where n is the data width in bits (32 or 64) of the operating system.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory as a hexadecimal number. The value must begin with a number (0–9) and must be followed by an X. For example, a value of 0fffx specifies 4,095 bytes of memory.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: specifies the minimum amount of memory available.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: specifies the maximum amount of memory available.

arguments.name: SVGAUTOPLAY
arguments.description: specifies to automatically start the animation in the web page.

arguments.name: SVGCONTROLBUTTONS
arguments.description: specifies to display the paging control buttons in the SVG document.

arguments.name: SVGFADEIN=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of seconds for an SVG frame to fade into view.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the number of seconds for an SVG frame to fade into view. Valid values can be any numeric representation (for example, .01, 5, or 6.5).

arguments.name: SVGFADEMODE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether an SVG frame overlaps the previous frame or whether each frame is played sequentially when a frame is fading in and out.

arguments.name: OVERLAP
arguments.description: specifies that for each SVG frame that is fading in or out of view, the fading of frames overlaps in the same time span.

arguments.name: SEQUENTIAL
arguments.description: specifies that for each SVG frame that is fading in or out of view, the frame fades out after the fade-out is complete. The next frame is a frame that is fading in.

arguments.name: SVGFADEOUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of seconds for an SVG frame to fade out of view.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the number of seconds for an SVG frame to fade out of view. Valid values can be any numeric representation (for example, .01, 5, or 6.5).

arguments.name: SVGHEIGHT=
arguments.description: Specifies the height of the viewport unless the SVG output is embedded in another SVG output; specifies the value of the height attribute of the outermost <svg> element in the SVG file.

arguments.name: number-of-
arguments.description: specifies the height as a number of unit-of-measure.

arguments.name: unit-of-measure
arguments.description: specifies the unit of measurement, which can be one of the following:
specifies to reset the height to the default value of 600 pixels.
specifies to reset the height to the default value of 600 pixels.

arguments.name: SVGMAGNIFYBUTTON
arguments.description: specifies to enable the SVG magnify tool in SVG documents.

arguments.name: SVGPRESERVEASPECTRATIO=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to force uniform scaling of SVG output; specifies the preserveAspectRatio attribute on the outermost <svg> element.

arguments.name: xMinYMin
arguments.description:
specifies to force uniform scaling by using the following alignment:
• Align the <min–x> of the element's viewBox with the smallest X value of the viewport.
• Align the <min–y> of the element's viewBox with the smallest Y value of the viewport.

arguments.name: xMidYMin
arguments.description:
specifies to force uniform scaling by using the following alignment:
• Align the midpoint X value of the element's viewBox with the midpoint X value of the viewport.
• Align the <min–y> of the element's viewBox with the smallest Y value of the viewport.

arguments.name: xMaxYMin
arguments.description:
specifies to force uniform scaling by using the following alignment:
• Align the <min–x>+<width> of the element's viewBox with the maximum X value of the viewport.
• Align the <min–y> of the element's viewBox with the smallest Y value of the viewport.

arguments.name: xMinYMid
arguments.description:
specifies to force uniform scaling by using the following alignment:
• Align the <min–x> of the element's viewBox with the smallest X value of the viewport.
• Align the midpoint Y value of the element's viewBox with the midpoint Y value of the viewport.

arguments.name: xMidYMid
arguments.description:
specifies to force uniform scaling by using the following alignment:
• Align the midpoint X value of the element's viewBox with the midpoint X value of the viewport.
• Align the midpoint Y value of the element's viewBox with the midpoint Y value of the viewport. This is the default.

arguments.name: xMaxYMid
arguments.description:
specifies to force uniform scaling by using the following alignment:
• Align the <min–x>+<width> of the element's viewBox with the maximum X value of the viewport.
• Align the midpoint Y value of the element's viewBox with the midpoint Y value of the viewport.

arguments.name: xMinYMax
arguments.description:
specifies to force uniform scaling by using the following alignment:
• Align the <min–x> of the element's viewBox with the smallest X value of the viewport.
• Align the <min–y>+<height> of the element's viewBox with the maximum Y value of the viewport.

arguments.name: xMidYMax
arguments.description:
specifies to force uniform scaling by using the following alignment:
• Align the midpoint X value of the element's viewBox with the midpoint X value of the viewport.
• Align the <min–y>+<height> of the element's viewBox with the maximum Y value of the viewport.

arguments.name: xMaxYMax
arguments.description:
specifies to force uniform scaling by using the following alignment:
• Align the <min–x>+<width> of the element's viewBox with the maximum X value of the viewport.
• Align the <min–y>+<height> of the element's viewBox with the maximum Y value of the viewport.

arguments.name: meet
arguments.description:
specifies to scale the SVG graphic as follows:
• preserve the aspect ratio
• make the entire viewBox visible within the viewport
• scale up the viewBox as much as possible while meeting other criteria

arguments.name: slice
arguments.description:
specifies to scale the SVG graphic as follows:
• preserve the aspect ratio
• cover the entire viewBox with the viewport
• scale down the viewBox as much as possible while meeting other criteria

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: specifies not to force uniform scaling and to scale the SVG output nonuniformly so that the element's bounding box exactly matches the viewport rectangle.
specifies to reset the preserveAspectRatio attribute of the <svg> element to the default value of xMidYMid meet.

arguments.name: SVGTITLE=
arguments.description: Specifies the title in the title bar of the SVG output; specifies the value of the <title> element in the SVG file.

arguments.name: "title"
arguments.description: specifies the title of the SVG.
specifies to reset the title to empty.
specifies to reset the title to empty.

arguments.name: SVGVIEWBOX=
arguments.description: Specifies the coordinates, width, and height that are used to set the viewBox attribute on the outermost <svg> element, which enables SVG output to scale to the viewport.

arguments.name: min–x
arguments.description: specifies the beginning x coordinate of the viewBox, in user units.

arguments.name: min–y
arguments.description: specifies the beginning y coordinate of the viewBox, in user units.

arguments.name: width
arguments.description: specifies the width of the viewBox, in user units.

arguments.name: height
arguments.description: specifies the height of the viewBox, in user units.

arguments.name: none
arguments.description: specifies that no viewBox attribute is to be specified on the outermost <svg> element, which effectively creates a static SVG document.
specifies to reset the width and height of the viewBox to the width and height of the paper size for the SVG printer.
specifies to reset the width and height of the viewBox to the width and height of the paper size for the SVG printer.

arguments.name: SVGWIDTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the width of the viewport unless the SVG output is embedded in another SVG output; specifies the value of the width attribute in the outermost <svg> element in the SVG file.

arguments.name: number-of-units
arguments.description: specifies the width as a number of unit-of-measure.

arguments.name: unit-of-measure
arguments.description: specifies the unit of measurement, which can be one of the following:
specifies to reset the width to the default value of 800 pixels.
specifies to reset the width to the default value of 800 pixels.

arguments.name: SVGX=
arguments.description: Specifies the x-axis coordinate of one corner of the rectangular region into which an embedded <svg> element is placed; specifies the x attribute in the outermost <svg> element in an SVG file.

arguments.name: number-of-units
arguments.description: specifies the x-axis coordinate as a number of unit-of-measure.

arguments.name: unit-of-measure
arguments.description: specifies the unit of measurement, which can be one of the following:
specifies to reset the x attribute to 0 on the <svg> element and the x-axis coordinate for embedded SVG to 0.
specifies to reset the x attribute to 0 on the <svg> element and the x-axis coordinate for embedded SVG to 0.

arguments.name: SVGY=
arguments.description: Specifies the y-axis coordinate of one corner of the rectangular region into which an embedded <svg> element is placed; specifies the y attribute in the outermost <svg> element in an SVG file.

arguments.name: number-of-units
arguments.description: specifies the y-axis coordinate as a number of unit-of-measure.

arguments.name: unit-of-measure
arguments.description: specifies the unit of measurement, which can be one of the following:
specifies to reset the y attribute on the <svg> element and the y-axis coordinate for embedded SVG output to 0.
specifies to reset the y attribute on the <svg> element and the y-axis coordinate for embedded SVG output to 0.

arguments.name: SYNTAXCHECK
arguments.description: enables syntax check mode for statements that are submitted within a non-interactive or batch SAS session.

arguments.name: TEXTURELOC=
arguments.description: Specifies the location of textures and images that are used by ODS styles.

arguments.name: location
arguments.description: specifies the location of textures and images used by ODS styles. Location can refer either to the physical name of the directory or to a URL reference to the directory.

arguments.name: THREADS
arguments.description: specifies to use threaded processing for SAS applications that support it.

arguments.name: TIMEZONE=
arguments.description: Specifies the user local time zone.

arguments.name: time-zone-name
arguments.description: specifies a three- or four-character time zone name. For example, EST is a time zone name for Eastern Time.

arguments.name: time-zone-ID
arguments.description: specifies a region/area value that is defined by SAS. When you specify a time zone ID, the time zone that SAS uses is determined by time zone name and daylight saving time rules.

arguments.name: TOPMARGIN=
arguments.description: Specifies the print margin at the top of the page.

arguments.name: margin-size
arguments.description: specifies the size of the margin.

arguments.name: <margin-unit>
arguments.description: specifies the units for margin-size. The margin-unit can be in for inches or cm for centimeters. <margin-unit> is saved as part of the value of the TOPMARGIN system option.

arguments.name: TRANTAB=
arguments.description: Specifies the translation tables that are used by various parts of SAS.

arguments.name: catalog-entries
arguments.description: specifies SAS catalog entries that contain translation tables. If you specify entry-name.type, SAS searches SASUSER.PROFILE first and then SASUSER.HOST.

arguments.name: UBUFNO=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of buffers to use for utility files.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the number of utility file buffers to be allocated in multiples of 1: 1,024 (kilo); 1,048,576 (mega); 1,073,741,824 (giga). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 buffers, and a value of .003k specifies 3 buffers.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the number of utility file buffers to be allocated in multiples of 1: 1,024 (kilo); 1,048,576 (mega); 1,073,741,824 (giga). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 buffers, and a value of .003k specifies 3 buffers.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the number of utility file buffers to be allocated in multiples of 1: 1,024 (kilo); 1,048,576 (mega); 1,073,741,824 (giga). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 buffers, and a value of .003k specifies 3 buffers.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the number of utility file buffers to be allocated in multiples of 1: 1,024 (kilo); 1,048,576 (mega); 1,073,741,824 (giga). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 buffers, and a value of .003k specifies 3 buffers.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the number of utility file buffers as a hexadecimal value. The value must begin with a number (0–9) and must be followed by an X. For example, the value 0fx specifies 15 buffers.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: sets the minimum number of utility file buffers to 0, which causes SAS to use the minimum optimal value for the operating environment.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: sets the number of utility file buffers to 20.

arguments.name: UBUFSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the buffer size for utility files.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the utility file buffer size in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the utility file buffer size in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the utility file buffer size in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the utility file buffer size in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: specifies the utility file buffer size in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the utility file buffer size as a hexadecimal value. The value must begin with a number (0–9) and must be followed by an X. For example, the value 2dx sets the page size to 45 bytes.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: sets the utility file buffer size to 0. A value of 0 specifies that the buffer size is set to the default page size for the operating environment.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: sets the utility buffer size to the maximum possible number in your operating environment, up to the largest four-byte, signed integer, which is 231-1, or approximately 2 billion bytes.

arguments.name: UPRINTCOMPRESSION
arguments.description: specifies to enable compression of files created by some Universal Printers and some SAS/GRAPH devices.

arguments.name: URLENCODING
arguments.description: Specifies whether the argument to the URLENCODE function and to the URLDECODE function is interpreted using the SAS session encoding or UTF-8 encoding.

arguments.name: URLENCODING=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the argument to the URLENCODE function and to the URLDECODE function is interpreted using the SAS session encoding or UTF-8 encoding.

arguments.name: SESSION
arguments.description: specifies that the argument to the URLENCODE function and to the URLDECODE function is interpreted using the SAS session encoding.

arguments.name: UTF8
arguments.description: specifies that the argument to the URLENCODE function and to the URLDECODE function is interpreted using UTF-8 encoding.

arguments.name: USER
arguments.description: Specifies the default permanent SAS library.

arguments.name: pathname
arguments.description: identifies the directory containing your default permanent SAS library. It must be a directory name.

arguments.name: libref
arguments.description: is the libref associated with the directory containing your default permanent SAS library. It must already be assigned.

arguments.name: UUIDCOUNT=
