arguments.description: Specifies the number of UUIDs to acquire from the UUID Generator Daemon.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the number of UUIDs to acquire. Zero indicates that the UUID Generator Daemon is not required.

arguments.name: VALIDFMTNAME=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum size (32 characters or 8 characters) that user-created format and informat names can be before an error or warning is issued.

arguments.name: LONG
arguments.description: specifies that format and informat names can be up to 32 alphanumeric characters.

arguments.name: FAIL
arguments.description: specifies that creating a format or informat name that is longer than eight characters results in an error message.

arguments.name: WARN
arguments.description: specifies that creating a format or informat name that is longer than eight characters results in a warning message to remind you that the format or informat cannot be used with releases prior to SAS 9.

arguments.name: VALIDMEMNAME=
arguments.description: Specifies the rules for naming SAS data sets, SAS data views, and item stores.

arguments.name: COMPATIBLE
arguments.description:
specifies that a SAS data set name, a SAS data view name, or an item store name must follow these rules:
• The length of the names can be up to 32 characters.
• Names must begin with a letter of the Latin alphabet (A–Z, a–z) or an underscore. Subsequent characters can be letters of the Latin alphabet, numerals, or underscores.
• Names cannot contain blanks or special characters except for the underscore.
• Names can contain mixed-case letters. SAS internally converts the member name to uppercase. Therefore, you cannot use the same member name with a different combination of uppercase and lowercase letters to represent different variables. For example, customer, Customer, and CUSTOMER all represent the same member name. How the name is saved on disk is determined by the operating environment.

arguments.name: EXTEND
arguments.description:
specifies that a SAS data set name, a SAS data view name, or an item store name must follow these rules:
• Names can include national characters.
• The name can include special characters, except for the / \ * ? " < > |: -. characters. 
• The name must contain at least one character (letters, numbers, valid special characters, and national characters).
• The length of the name can be up to 32 bytes. 
• Null bytes are not allowed.
• Names cannot begin with a blank or a ‘.’ (the period).
• Leading and trailing blanks are deleted when the member is created.
• Names can contain mixed-case letters. SAS internally converts the member name to uppercase. Therefore, you cannot use the same member name with a different combination of uppercase and lowercase letters to represent different variables. For example, customer, Customer, and CUSTOMER all represent the same member name. How the name appears is determined by the operating environment.

arguments.name: VALIDVARNAME
arguments.description: Specifies the rules for valid SAS column names that can be created and processed during a SAS session.

arguments.name: V7
arguments.description:
specifies that column names must follow these rules:
• can be up to 32 characters in length.
• must begin with a letter of the Latin alphabet (A - Z, a - z) or the underscore character. Subsequent characters can be letters of the Latin alphabet, numerals, or underscores.
• cannot contain blanks. 
• cannot contain special characters except for the underscore.
• can contain mixed-case letters. SAS stores and writes the column name in the same case that is used in the first reference to the column. However, when SAS processes a column name, SAS internally converts it to uppercase. You cannot, therefore, use the same column name with a different combination of uppercase and lowercase letters to represent different columns. For example, cat, Cat, and CAT all represent the same column. 
• cannot be assigned the names of special SAS automatic columns (such as _N_ and _ERROR_) or column list names (such as  _NUMERIC_, _CHARACTER_, and _ALL_).

arguments.name: UPCASE
arguments.description: specifies that the column name follows the same rules as V7, except that the column name is uppercase, as in earlier versions of SAS.

arguments.name: ANY
arguments.description:
specifies that SAS column names must follow these rules:
• can be up to 32 characters in length. 
• can begin with or contain any characters, including blanks.
• can contain mixed-case letters. SAS stores and writes the column name in the same case that is used in the first reference to the column. However, when SAS processes a column name, SAS internally converts it to uppercase. You cannot, therefore, use the same column name with a different combination of uppercase and lowercase letters to represent different columns. For example, cat, Cat, and CAT all represent the same column.

arguments.name: VALIDVARNAME=
arguments.description: Specifies the rules for valid SAS variable names that can be created and processed during a SAS session.

arguments.name: V7
arguments.description:
specifies that variable names must follow these rules:
• The name can be up to 32 characters.
• The first character must begin with a letter of the Latin alphabet (A - Z, a - z) or the underscore. Subsequent characters can be letters of the Latin alphabet, numerals, or underscores.
• Trailing blanks are ignored. The variable name alignment is left-justified. 
• A variable name cannot contain blanks or special characters except for the underscore.
• A variable name can contain mixed-case letters. SAS stores and writes the variable name in the same case that is used in the first reference to the variable. However, when SAS processes a variable name, SAS internally converts it to uppercase. Therefore, you cannot use the same variable name with a different combination of uppercase and lowercase letters to represent different variables. For example, cat, Cat, and CAT all represent the same variable. 
• Do not assign variables the names of special SAS automatic variables (such as _N_ and _ERROR_) or variable list names (such as  _NUMERIC_, _CHARACTER_, and _ALL_) to variables.

arguments.name: UPCASE
arguments.description: specifies that the variable name follows the same rules as V7, except that the variable name is uppercase, as in earlier versions of SAS.

arguments.name: ANY
arguments.description:
specifies that SAS variable names must follow these rules:
• The name can begin with or contain any characters, including blanks, national characters, special characters, and multi-byte characters.
• The name can be up to 32  bytes in length.
• The name cannot contain any null bytes.
• Leading blanks are preserved, but trailing blanks are ignored.
• The name must contain at least one character. A name with all blanks is not permitted.
• The name can contain mixed-case letters. SAS stores and writes the variable name in the same case that is used in the first reference to the variable. However, when SAS processes a variable name, SAS internally converts it to uppercase. Therefore, you cannot use the same variable name with a different combination of uppercase and lowercase letters to represent different variables. For example, cat, Cat, and CAT all represent the same variable.

arguments.name: VARINITCHK=
arguments.description: Specifies whether a DATA step stops or continues executing when a variable is not initialized and the type of message to write to the SAS log.

arguments.name: NONOTE
arguments.description: specifies that the DATA step continues to execute without writing a message to the SAS log when a variable is not initialized.

arguments.name: NOTE
arguments.description: specifies that the DATA step continues to execute and writes a note to the SAS log when a variable is not initialized.

arguments.name: WARN
arguments.description: specifies that the DATA step continues to execute and writes a warning message to the SAS log when a variable is not initialized.

arguments.name: ERROR
arguments.description: specifies that the DATA step stops executing and writes an error message to the SAS log when a variable is not initialized.

arguments.name: VARLENCHK=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of message to write to the SAS log when the input data set is read using the SET, MERGE, UPDATE, or MODIFY statements.

arguments.name: NOWARN
arguments.description: specifies that no warning message is issued when the length of a variable that is being read is larger than the length that is defined for the variable.

arguments.name: WARN
arguments.description: specifies that a warning is issued when the length of a variable that is being read is larger than the length that is defined for the variable.

arguments.name: ERROR
arguments.description: specifies that an error message is issued when the length of a variable that is being read is larger than the length that is defined for the variable.

arguments.name: VBUFSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the size of the view buffer.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the size of the view buffer in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the size of the view buffer in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the size of the view buffer in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the size of the view buffer in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: specifies the size of the view buffer in multiples of 1 (bytes); 1,024 (kilobytes); 1,048,576 (megabytes); 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes); or 1,099,511,627,776 (terabytes). For example, a value of 8 specifies 8 bytes, and a value of 3m specifies 3,145,728 bytes.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies the size of the view buffer as a hexadecimal value. The value must begin with a number (0–9) and must be followed by an X. For example, the value 0fffeX specifies a buffer size of 65,534 bytes.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: sets the minimum number of buffers to 0.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: sets the view buffer size to 263–1, or approximately 9.2 quintillion bytes.

arguments.name: VNFERR
arguments.description: specifies that SAS issue an error when a BY variable exists in one data set but not in another data set when the other data set is _NULL_. This option applies when processing the SET, MERGE, UPDATE, or MODIFY statements. When the error occurs, SAS enters into syntax-check mode.

arguments.name: NOVNFERR
arguments.description: specifies that SAS issue a warning when a BY variable exists in one data set but not in another data set when the other data set is _NULL_. This option applies when processing the SET, MERGE, UPDATE, or MODIFY statements. When the warning occurs, SAS does not enter into syntax-check mode.

arguments.name: WORKTERM
arguments.description: erases the Work files at the termination of a SAS session.

arguments.name: XCMD
arguments.description: specifies that the X command is valid in the current SAS session.

arguments.name: YEARCUTOFF=
arguments.description: Specifies the first year of a 100-year span that is used by date informats and functions to read a two-digit year.

arguments.name: nnnn
arguments.description: specifies the first year of the 100-year span.

arguments.name: _LAST_=
arguments.description: Specifies the most recently created data set.

arguments.name: SAS-data-set
arguments.description: specifies a SAS data set name.

name: PAGE
description: Skips to a new page in the SAS log.

name: PATTERN
description: Defines the characteristics of patterns used in maps.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color of the fill. Pattern-color is any SAS/GRAPH color name. The _STYLE_ value specifies the appropriate color based on the current style. See .

arguments.name: IMAGE=
arguments.description: specifies an image file that is used to fill one or more areas of a map. The format of the external file specification varies across operating environments. See the companion reference for your specific operating environment.

arguments.name: IMAGESTYLE=
arguments.description: specifies how the image specified in the IMAGE= option is to be applied to fill a map. The TILE value repeats the image as needed to fill the map. The FIT value stretches a single instance of the image to fill the map.

arguments.name: REPEAT=
arguments.description: specifies the number of times that a PATTERN definition is applied before the next PATTERN definition is used.

arguments.name: VALUE=
arguments.description: Patterns are specified for the blocks in block maps produced by the BLOCK statement in the GMAP procedure. (The map area from which the block rises takes a map pattern as described in the option .) See also .

arguments.name: EMPTY
arguments.description: an empty pattern. The ActiveX control does not support EMPTY.

arguments.name: SOLID
arguments.description: a solid pattern (the only valid value for three-dimensional charts).

arguments.name: L
arguments.description: specifies left-slanting lines.

arguments.name: R
arguments.description: specifies right-slanting lines.

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies crosshatched lines.

arguments.name: VALUE=
arguments.description: specifies patterns for the following:

arguments.name: MEMPTY
arguments.description: specifies an empty pattern.

arguments.name: MSOLID
arguments.description: specifies a solid pattern.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies a shaded pattern.

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: specifies parallel lines (the default).

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies crosshatched lines.

arguments.name: VALUE=
arguments.description: specifies patterns for pie and star charts produced by the PIE and STAR statements in the GCHART procedure. Values for pie/star-pattern are as follows:

arguments.name: PEMPTY
arguments.description: specifies an empty pattern. EMPTY or E are also valid aliases.

arguments.name: PSOLID
arguments.description: specifies a solid pattern. SOLID or S are also valid aliases.

arguments.name: P
arguments.description: specifies a shaded pattern.

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: specifies parallel lines (the default).

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies crosshatched lines.

name: RESETLINE
description: Restarts the program line numbers in the SAS log to 1.

name: RUN
description: Executes the previously entered SAS statements.

arguments.name: CANCEL
arguments.description: terminates the current step without executing it. SAS prints a message that indicates that the step was not executed.

name: SASFILE
description: Opens a SAS data set and allocates enough buffers to hold the entire file in memory.

arguments.name: libref
arguments.description: a name that is associated with a SAS library. The libref (library reference) must be a valid SAS name. The default libref is either User (if assigned) or Work (if User is not assigned).

arguments.name: member-name
arguments.description: a valid SAS name that is a SAS data file. The data file is a member of the SAS library associated with the libref.

arguments.name: member-type
arguments.description: the type of SAS file to be opened. A valid value is DATA, which is the default.

arguments.name: ENCRYPTKEY=
arguments.description: enables the SASFILE statement to open an AES-encrypted SAS data file. If a SAS data file is encrypted with the AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) algorithm, a key value is assigned to the file and must be specified in order to access the file. The key value can be up to 64 bytes long.

arguments.name: READ=
arguments.description: enables the SASFILE statement to open a read-protected file. The password must be a valid SAS name.

arguments.name: WRITE=
arguments.description: enables the SASFILE statement to use the WRITE password to open a file that is both read-protected and write-protected. The password must be a valid SAS name.

arguments.name: ALTER=
arguments.description: enables the SASFILE statement to use the ALTER password to open a file that is both read-protected and alter-protected. The password must be a valid SAS name.

arguments.name: PW=
arguments.description: enables the SASFILE statement to use the password to open a file that is assigned for all levels of protection. The password must be a valid SAS name.

arguments.name: OPEN
arguments.description: opens the file, allocates the buffers, but defers reading the data into memory until a procedure, statement, or application is executed.

arguments.name: LOAD
arguments.description: opens the file, allocates the buffers, and reads the data into memory.

arguments.name: CLOSE
arguments.description: frees the buffers and closes the file.

name: SKIP
description: Creates a blank line in the SAS log.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the number of blank lines that you want to create in the log.

name: SYMBOL
description: Defines the characteristics of symbols that display the data plotted by a PLOT statement used by the GBARLINE, GCONTOUR, and GPLOT procedures.
help:
SYMBOL <1 - 255>
	<COLOR=symbol-color | _style_> 
	<MODE=EXCLUDE | INCLUDE> 
	<REPEAT=number-of-times> 
	<STEP=distance<units>> 
	<BWIDTH=box-width> 
	<CI=line-color | _style_> 
	<CO=color> 
	<CV=value-color | _style_> 
	<FONT="font"> 
	<HEIGHT=symbol-height<units>> 
	<LINE=line-type> 
	<POINTLABEL<=(label-description(s)) | NONE>> 
	<VALUE=special-symbol | text-string | SPECIAL | NONE> 
	<WIDTH=thickness-factor>
	<INTERPOL=interpolation-option> 
	<SINGULAR=n>;

arguments.name: BWIDTH=
arguments.description: specifies the width of the box generated by either the INTERPOL=BOX or INTERPOL=HILOB option.

arguments.name: CI=
arguments.description: specifies a color for an interpolation line (GPLOT and GBARLINE) or a contour line (GCONTOUR).

arguments.name: CO=
arguments.description: specifies a color for outlines of filled areas, confidence limit lines, and staffs, boxes, and bars.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies a color for the entire definition, unless it is followed by a more explicit specification.

arguments.name: CV=
arguments.description: specifies a color for plot symbols, filled areas, and contour labels.

arguments.name: FONT=
arguments.description: specifies the font for the plot symbol (GPLOT, GBARLINE) or contour labels (GCONTOUR) specified by the VALUE= option.

arguments.name: HEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the height in number of units of plot symbols (GPLOT, GBARLINE) or contour labels (GCONTOUR).

arguments.name: INTERPOL=
arguments.description: specifies the interpolation method for the plot.

arguments.name: BOX
arguments.description: produces box-and-whisker plots.

arguments.name: F
arguments.description: fills the box with the color specified by CV= and outlines the box with the color specified by CO=

arguments.name: J
arguments.description: joins the median points of the boxes with a line

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: draws tops and bottoms on the whiskers.
specifies high or low extremes. INTERPOL=BOX00 is not the same as the default, INTERPOL=BOX.
specifies 1st percentile low, 99th high.
specifies 5th percentile low, 95th high.
specifies 10th percentile low, 90th high.
specifies 25th percentile low, 75th high. Because the box extends from the 25th to the 75th percentile, no whiskers are produced.

arguments.name: HILO
arguments.description: specifies that a solid vertical line connect the minimum and maximum Y values for each X value.

arguments.name: C
arguments.description: draws tick marks at the close value instead of at the mean value. Specifying C assumes that there are three values of Y (HIGH, LOW, and CLOSE) for every value of X. If more or fewer than three Y values are specified, the mean is ticked. The Y values can be in any order in the input data set.

arguments.name: B
arguments.description: connects the minimum and maximum Y values with bars instead of lines. Use the BWIDTH= option to increase the width of the bars.

arguments.name: J
arguments.description: joins the mean values or the close values (if HILOC is specified) with a line. This point is not marked with a tick mark. You cannot use the PLOT statement option AREAS= with INTERPOL=HILOJ.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: adds tops and bottoms to each line.

arguments.name: BJ
arguments.description: connects maximum and minimum values with a bar and joins the mean or close values.

arguments.name: TJ
arguments.description: adds tops and bottoms to the lines and joins the mean or close values.

arguments.name: JOIN
arguments.description: connects data points with straight lines.

arguments.name: L
arguments.description: specifies a Lagrange interpolation to smooth the plot line.
specifies the degree of the Lagrange interpolation polynomial. By default, degree is 1.
specifies the degree of the Lagrange interpolation polynomial. By default, degree is 1.
specifies the degree of the Lagrange interpolation polynomial. By default, degree is 1.

arguments.name: P
arguments.description: specifies a parametric interpolation.

arguments.name: S
arguments.description: sorts a data set by the independent variable before plotting its data.

arguments.name: MEMPTY
arguments.description: specifies an empty pattern. EMPTY and E are valid aliases.

arguments.name: MSOLID
arguments.description: specifies a solid pattern. SOLID and S are valid aliases

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies a shaded pattern.

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: specifies parallel lines (the default)

arguments.name: X
arguments.description: specifies crosshatched lines.

arguments.name: NEEDLE
arguments.description: draws a vertical line from each data point to a horizontal line at the 0 value on the vertical axis or the minimum value on the vertical axis.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: suppresses any interpolation and, if the VALUE= option is not specified, also suppresses plot points.

arguments.name: R
arguments.description: specifies that a plot is a regression analysis.

arguments.name: L
arguments.description: requests linear regression representing the regression equation

arguments.name: Q
arguments.description: requests quadratic regression representing the regression equation

arguments.name: C
arguments.description: requests cubic regression representing the regression equation

eliminates the β 0 parameter, or intercept, from the regression equation. If the origin is at (0,0), also forces the regression line through the origin. For example, if you specify 0 for a linear regression, the plot line represents the equation

arguments.name: CLM
arguments.description: displays confidence limits for mean predicted values.

arguments.name: CLI
arguments.description: displays confidence limits for individual predicted values.

arguments.name: SM
arguments.description: specifies that a smooth line is fit to data using a spline routine.

produces a cubic spline that minimizes a linear combination of the sum of squares of the residuals of fit and the integral of the square of the second derivativeC.H. Reinsch, “Smoothing by Spline Functions,” Numerische Mathematik 10 (1967): 177–183.. The greater the nn value, the smoother the fitted curve. By default, the value of nn is 0.

arguments.name: P
arguments.description: specifies a parametric cubic spline.

arguments.name: S
arguments.description: sorts data by the independent variable before plotting.

arguments.name: SPLINE
arguments.description: specifies that the interpolation for the plot line use a spline routine.

arguments.name: P
arguments.description: specifies a parametric spline interpolation method. This interpolation uses a parametric spline method with continuous second derivatives. Using the method described earlier for the spline interpolation, a parametric spline is fitted to both the horizontal and vertical values. The parameter used is the distance between points

arguments.name: S
arguments.description: sorts a data set by the independent variable before plotting its data.

arguments.name: STD
arguments.description: specifies that a solid line connect the mean Y value with ± 1, 2, or 3 standard deviations for each X.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: computes s sub y with macron above end sub sy¯ .

arguments.name: P
arguments.description: computes sample variances using a pooled estimate, as in a one-way ANOVA model.

arguments.name: B
arguments.description: connects the minimum and maximum Y values with bars instead of lines.

arguments.name: J
arguments.description: connects the means from bar to bar with a line.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: adds tops and bottoms to each line.

arguments.name: BJ
arguments.description: connects maximum and minimum values with a bar and joins the mean values.

arguments.name: TJ
arguments.description: adds tops and bottoms to the lines and joins the mean values.

arguments.name: STEP
arguments.description: specifies that the data are plotted with a step function.

arguments.name: L
arguments.description: displays the data point on the left of the step.

arguments.name: R
arguments.description: displays the data point on the right of the step.

arguments.name: C
arguments.description: displays the data point in the center of the step.

arguments.name: J
arguments.description: produces steps joined with a vertical line.

arguments.name: S
arguments.description: sorts unordered data by the independent variable before plotting.

arguments.name: LINE=
arguments.description: specifies the line type of plot or contour lines.
specifies a solid line.
specifies a dashed line.

arguments.name: MODE=
arguments.description: specifies that any interpolation method exclude or include data values that are outside the range of plot axes.

arguments.name: POINTLABEL
arguments.description: labels plot points.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color of the label text.

arguments.name: DROPCOLLISIONS
arguments.description: specify DROPCOLLISIONS to drop new labels if they collide with a label already in use. Specify NODROPCOLLISIONS to retain all labels. The default is DROPCOLLISIONS.

arguments.name: NODROPCOLLISIONS
arguments.description: specify DROPCOLLISIONS to drop new labels if they collide with a label already in use. Specify NODROPCOLLISIONS to retain all labels. The default is DROPCOLLISIONS.

arguments.name: FONT=
arguments.description: specifies the font for the text. See for details about specifying font. If you omit FONT=, a font specification is searched for in this order:

arguments.name: HEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the height of the text characters in number of units. By default, HEIGHT=1 CELL. If you omit HEIGHT=, a text height specification is searched for in this order:

arguments.name: JUSTIFY=
arguments.description: specifies the horizontal alignment of the label text. The default is CENTER. The location of the point label is relative to the location of the corresponding data point.

arguments.name: POSITION=
arguments.description: specifies the vertical placement of the label text. The default is TOP. The location of the point label is relative to the location of the corresponding data point.

specifies the variable or variables whose values label the plot points, and the delimiter between more than one variable. The variable specification must be enclosed in either single or double quotation marks. The first specified variable must be prefixed with a number sign (#). If a second variable is specified, it must be prefixed with a colon and a number sign (:#). When you specify two variables, you can also specify the character to display as the delimiter between variable values in the plot label.

arguments.name: REPEAT=
arguments.description: specifies the number of times that a SYMBOL definition is applied before the next SYMBOL definition is used.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: tunes the algorithm used to check for singularities.

arguments.name: STEP=
arguments.description: specifies the minimum distance between labels on contour lines

arguments.name: VALUE=
arguments.description: specifies a plot symbol for the data points (GPLOT and GBARLINE).

arguments.name: WIDTH=
arguments.description: specifies the thickness of interpolated lines (GPLOT) or contour lines (GCONTOUR).

name: SYSECHO
description: Sends a global statement complete event and passes a text string back to the IOM client.

arguments.name: "text"
arguments.description: specifies a text string that is passed back to the IOM client.

name: TITLE
description: Controls the content, appearance, and placement of text in a title.

arguments.description: specifies the relative line that contains the title text.

arguments.name: BCOLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the background color of the title block.

arguments.name: BOLD
arguments.description: specifies that the font weight is bold for the text string.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color for the text. You can specify colors using a number of different color-naming schemes. For more information, see .

arguments.name: FONT=
arguments.description: specifies the system font to use for the subsequent text string. If you supply multiple fonts, then the destination device uses the first one that is installed on your system.

arguments.name: HEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the size of the text. You can also specify the unit of measurement. Without a unit of measure, the number becomes a relative size.

arguments.name: numeric-value
arguments.description: The value of size is relative to all other font sizes in the HTML document.

arguments.name: units
arguments.description: is a nonnegative number.

arguments.name: ITALIC
arguments.description: specifies that the font style is italic for the text string.

arguments.name: JUSTIFY=
arguments.description: specifies the alignment of the text string. You can specify one of the following values:

arguments.name: LEFT
arguments.description: aligns the text to the left.

arguments.name: CENTER
arguments.description: aligns the text in the center.

arguments.name: RIGHT
arguments.description: aligns the text to the right.

arguments.name: LINK=
arguments.description: specifies a uniform resource locator (URL) to which a title links.

arguments.name: UNDERLIN=
arguments.description: specifies whether the subsequent text is underlined. UNDERLIN=0 indicates no underlining. Values 1, 2, and 3 indicate the same type of underlining.

arguments.name: ALT=
arguments.description: specifies descriptive text for a URL to which a title links, or the title itself.

arguments.name: ANGLE=
arguments.description: specifies the angle of the baseline of the entire text string with respect to the horizontal.

arguments.name: BLANK=
arguments.description: protects the box and its contents from being overwritten by any subsequent graphics elements.

arguments.name: BOX=
arguments.description: draws a box around one line of text.

arguments.name: BSPACE=
arguments.description: specifies the amount of space between the text and the border of a box that you create with the BOX= option.

arguments.name: DRAW=
arguments.description: draws lines anywhere on the graphics output area.

arguments.name: LANGLE=
arguments.description: specifies the angle of one or more than one entire text-string.

arguments.name: LSPACE=
arguments.description: specifies the amount of space above lines of title text.

arguments.name: MOVE=
arguments.description: positions a text string.

arguments.name: ROTATE=
arguments.description: specifies the angle at which each character of text is rotated.

arguments.name: WRAP
arguments.description: wraps a text string containing a blank to a second line if the text does not fit on one line.

arguments.name: 'text-string'
arguments.description: is a text string with a maximum length if 255 bytes. You must enclose text strings in either single or double quotation marks. The text appears exactly as you enter it in the statement, including uppercase and lowercase characters and spaces. Titles automatically wrap to additional lines if necessary. If the length of the specified title is greater than the value of the LINESIZE option, the title is truncated to the line size.

name: TRANTAB
description: Specifies the translation table to use when you transcode character data in order to export or transfer a SAS file.

arguments.name: NAME=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the translation table to apply to the SAS catalog that you want to export (PROC CPORT) or transfer (PROC UPLOAD or PROC DOWNLOAD). The translation-table-name that you specify as the name of a catalog entry in either your SASUSER.PROFILE catalog or the SASHELP.HOST catalog. The SASUSER.PROFILE catalog is searched first, and then the SASHELP.HOST catalog is searched.

arguments.name: TYPE=
arguments.description: applies the translation table only to the entries with the type or types that you specify. The etype-list can be one or more entry types. Examples of catalog entry types include DATA and FORMAT. If etype-list is a simple entry type, omit the parentheses.

arguments.name: OPT=
arguments.description: If you do not specify the OPT= option, the UPLOAD or DOWNLOAD procedure applies the translation table to all of the entries in the catalog that you specify.

name: X
description: Issues an operating-environment command from within a SAS session.

arguments.name: 'operating-environment-command'
arguments.description: specifies a Linux command. If you specify only one command, you do not need to enclose the command in quotation marks. Separate multiple commands with a semi-colon (;).
